text: Hector Gracia, born in Spain, is an author and an aspiring philosopher. He has been living in Japan for 18 years. He worked as a software engineer in Switzerland before moving to Japan. His most well-known books are Ikigai, A Geek in Japan, and Ichigo Ichie.Francesc Miralles, also born in Spain, is an award-winning author of fiction, self-help, and inspirational books. He studied journalism, English literature, and German. He has also worked as an editor, translator, ghostwriter, and musician. He is well-known for his book Ikigai and Love in Lowercase.The authors of Ikigai have interviewed hundreds of centenarians of Japan to unravel their secret of being young and happy, even at an old age. Most of the Japanese belonged to Okinawa, a Japanese Island, where 24 people out of 100,000 are over the age of 100- far more than the global average. Women of Okinawa live longer and have fewer diseases than anywhere else in the world. The book contains lessons based on what these Japanese centenarians eat and drink, how they treat their work and their style of living.The book introduces the concept of ikigai and how it helps the Japanese people live a healthy life even at an old age. Then the authors describe the secrets of anti-aging and how stress can degrade our health. Concepts of Logo-therapy and case studies where people found their purpose are described. The basic principles of Morita Therapy are also explained. In the next chapter, the authors explain flow, three steps through which flow can be achieved in work, and how you can discover your ikigai with the help of flow.The following chapters contain some information about Japanese centenarians and their philosophy, habits, lifestyle, and diet. Then the book explains some yoga and exercises of Japanese people which keeps them healthy. The last chapter contains the concept of resilience and antifragility, which can help you handle lifeâ€™s challenges without getting broken. The book ends with an epilogue that includes the ten rules of ikigai.Three key lessons which I have learned from the book is as follows-(1)â€œIkigaiâ€ is a Japanese word that means- a reason for living, a meaning for living. Having an ikigai means having a clear purpose that makes our life worthwhile. Your ikigai is something you love (watching Netflix, scrolling Instagram, sleeping, etc. wonâ€™t count), you are good at, you can be paid for, and something the world needs. For example, if you love singing a lot and are good at it, your ikigai is probably singing. The world needs good songs, and you can be paid for them.So, first, you need to find your ikigai or purpose, and then you should constantly take action to fulfill this purpose. The good news is this action wouldnâ€™t seem boring because it will give a sense of satisfaction. If you have a definite purpose, an Ikigai, you would never feel lost.â€œHe who has a why to live for can bear with almost any how.â€-Viktor Frankl, an Austrian neurologist(2)Work with the flowWe all have experienced a situation in our lives where we lost track of time. It may be when you were reading a book, and you got so much immersed in it that you didnâ€™t realize how 3 hours passed like a flash of light. But there are also times when the opposite happens, and time doesnâ€™t pass at all. You have probably experienced this during a boring lecture. What causes this difference? Why does time pass slowly when we do something that we donâ€™t like while it passes swiftly when we do something of our interest?The answer is flow. Ta-dah! The psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi coined the term flow and described it as the pleasure we feel when we completely immerse ourselves in what we are doing. According to him,The state in which people are so involved in an activity that nothing else seems to matter; the experience itself is so enjoyable that people will do it even at a great cost, for the sheer shake of doing it.When we are in a state of flow, we focus on our work and not on distractions. The intensity of focus leads to Deep Work which increases our productivity and at the same time gives satisfaction. Once we find flow in our work, the work will be fun.(3)Be resilientThis is the most powerful lesson which I learned from the book Ikigaiâ€“ to be resilient. Resilience is defined as the ability to withstand harm without getting weakened. It means to accept everything life throws at us, without blaming others, without getting frustrated, without feeling discouraged.When you have a clearly defined ikigai, you have to pursue it no matter how difficult the situation becomes. You canâ€™t give up even if things are not going according to your expectation. Thatâ€™s when the importance of resilience comes. Resilience is our ability to deal with setbacks. The more resilient we are, the easier it will be to handle the obstacles without getting broken. Those who are resilient, they are good at dealing with negative situations without getting discouraged. They adapt to changes and concentrate only on those things which they can change.What did i liked about Ikigai?First of all, I liked the concept of ikigai and how our ikigai can help us live a meaningful life. This is life-changing. The concept of flow and how to experience flow in our work was the most beautiful chapter in the book. I liked it so much that I made notes of this concept. I also liked the part where the authors describe resilience and anti-fragility.The book made me feel the importance of slowing down, being in the moment, and showing gratitude for every small thing I have in this life. This book helped me to live with peace, make friends, and enjoy each and every moment. I donâ€™t know; the book is a kind of magic, which made me realize that there is nothing to worry about but only to be happy. I was happy after reading it.What didnâ€™t I like about Ikigai?Before reading the book, I expected that this book is all about ikigai and finding purpose and will help me find my own. But when I read it, I found that it doesnâ€™t contain much information about finding ikigai, which disappointed me. The book includes advice about exercises and eating vegetables, which are somewhat familiar and can be found in any blog. These were the few things that I didnâ€™t like in the book.Is Ikigai worth reading?Yes, the book Ikigai is worth reading because it contains many powerful and proven concepts which can help you to improve your way of living. It can help you realize the value of a purposeful life and find your purpose. In todayâ€™s stressful and fast-paced world, we rarely get any time to heal our body, mind, and soul. This book can help you to understand the importance of slowing down and being in the present. If you feel bored in life, Ikigai can help you to enjoy and get lost in your work. This book contains interviews of Japanese centenarians, which would motivate you to live a simple life with high thinking. I found all the lessons highly practical, which anyone can easily implement in their life and get remarkable results.Who should read Ikigai?The book Ikigai must be read by all those people who donâ€™t enjoy their work and are frustrated, or who are stressed and busy in their work and hardly live their life, or who doesnâ€™t have a purpose in life and feels lost, or who are discouraged by failures, or all of the above. This book can also help those people who donâ€™t have a good lifestyle, eat junk foods, donâ€™t exercise, drink and smoke, etc. Ikigai can make anyone understand the importance of living a purposeful life. I will recommend this book to anyone who wants to live a long, happy, and purposeful life.

text: I personally believe that having a purpose on in life and then giving it your all is the most important to lead a happy life. This book validates so.Ikigai is a short but not very short book based on a Japanese concept. According to this concept, we find the deeply sown purpose of our lives from within ourselves by defining our passion, mission, vocation and profession. It gives you tips as to how the simplest things in our life, like sometimes, taking a pause, are what will give us a long and happy life.I bought a hardcover because of itâ€™s extremely pretty cover. The cover itself will soothe your mind whenever you look at it. The title does go with the book but personally for me, not as I thought it would.If you are expecting it to help you find your Ikigai, give you step by step solution as to how you can find it and reward it with millions of dollars, youâ€™ll be disappointed. This book is full of facts, real life experience from Japanâ€™s Okinawa and compels you to focus more on you : your health, your choices, your focus and your inner happiness. It will probably be the only book youâ€™ll come across that tells you to take it, relax, but also burn in your passion.The language is as simplistic and beautiful as the cover and itâ€™s content. Not many tough words and very beginner-friendly in the reading world. The structure to is great with a prologue, 9 chapters, an epilogue and a list of more suggestions for you to explore in the end.Coming to the overall feel of the book, itâ€™s very cozy. In itâ€™s own way, it also does help you slightly to find your own Ikigai.I thought it would be a full on hustle kind of book but I felt relaxed after this read. I was ready to take on my tasks stress-free. Though it is not something extremely crazy and different, it definitely is a one-time read for all the hustlers or non-hustlers out there who think they have to punish themselves to get what they want.

date: Reviewed in India ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ on 7 January 2023
title: Simple yet profound

text: The title of the book suggests that it is unravelling The Japanese Secrets to a Long and Happy Life, but it also does incorporate the key elements from Indian way of life i.e.Yoga and the Chinese way of life i.e. Tai Chi. Indeed the key point that emerges from the book is that one should keep on moving and not spend most of the time of the day either sitting or lying down.It also dispels the notion that one should start withdrawing from the activities after one is officially retired and advocated that staying active is what would be the deciding factor if one aspires to complete a century on this planet- which incidentally is a Japanese quote from where the book starts. Does it not seem so pertinent in the times that we are living in- the Corona times. IKIGAI actually means living a meaningful life. Though Japan is a major rice growing country, the book advocates drawing from the patterns of food from people residing in Okinawa in Japan is that the food plate construct on a daily basis should be dominated by vegetables and Tofu,  and there is a particular emphasis on the size of the plate. The plate should not be large, as we normally have in Indian conditions but it should be of medium size.However  one may be hungry, one should aspire to eat 80% only which is called as Hara hachi bu in Japanese and were we to follow the maxim it would take care of quite a lot of health related issues that we are confronted with, associated with over eating.Interestingly enough Japanese have been practising the concept of saving called as Moai-where farmers get together to share best practices and also help one another with meager harvests. In the times of distress that the farming community is in the country, can we aspire to have such kind of a group of farmers. Farmers Producers Organizations have been formed but they need to converge to the concept of Moai to make it really effective.This group also had the provision of a monthly contribution akin the idea of SELF HELP GROUPS with a difference that the contribution is utilised for social activities and left over from the contribution is given a member based on his requirements.The book has tried to assimilate other such initiatives from around the world but the bottom line is that one has to find flow in everything that one is doing.  There should not be any distraction or multi-tasking at all as it does not help anyway. To attain the flow, the authors have requested to adopt the policy of leaving the cell phones one hour before going to sleep, and one hour after getting up. Tough act to adopt? Each one of us has a passion inside us or the Ikigai and if we have found it we need to practice and fine tune it, and if not yet, it is incumbent upon us to discover it.NALIN RAI

text: "Ikigai" is a wonderful book that introduces readers to the Japanese concept of finding your purpose in life. The author provides a practical framework for discovering your "ikigai" and shares inspiring stories of people who have found their true calling. The book is a great blend of Eastern philosophy and Western practicality and is written in an easy-to-read style that makes it accessible to everyone. If you are looking for guidance on how to live a more purposeful and fulfilling life, then "Ikigai" is definitely worth a read. I loved it very much. Thank you Amazon.

text: This print edition seems different from what I have seen in bookstores. The book is just 13x18 cms though it is hardcover as per listing and the page and print quality are good. Amazon delivered it in 5 days as usual.The book is really overhyped and though it makes for good one-time reading to discover all the hype around it, it is of little practical use, as the lifestyle of inhabitants of Okinawa is vastly different from urban living we are used to. Some of the activities Okinawans to, such as being physically active thru the day, eating a balanced diet, participating in community activities for shared interdependence, etc. can be practiced by city dwellers to some extent only. That the authors were too taken in by the lifestyle of Okinawans is evident from the detailed description of their daily habits, including several pages on exercise regimen like yoga (though some info is incorrect), Tai Chi, etc. which one can only learn by practicing oneself, not by reading in a book. The basic premise of the book may not apply to city folks as the lifestyle is that of folks who live on distant ldyllic places without the pressures of urban living. Okinawa can be one's dream destination to spend in one's sunset years, but very unlikely to inspire one to lead a similar lifestyle in the fast-paced metro / cities we live in. Cut down the hype guys.

title: Must read!!

text: To be completely honest I bought this book just because of its cover. I mean just take a moment and observe it, the perfect shade of blue with white flowers. Simplicity at its best. This book has some sort of vibe, I still remember how I smiled when I opened the amazon parcel and found this bundle of positivity and happiness. The sheer pleasure of caressing its pages which is very different as compared to the regular pages of other novels, it gives you immense relief Idk how and why, but it does. Coming to the main content, the book starts by telling the meaning of Ikigai i.e.,purpose of your life, reason to get out of your bed every morning happily and how finding your Ikigai will lead to a long and happy life. The importance of society and a friendly neighbourhood is well put.The interviews of the Japanese Centenarians explains why they are the longest living human beings on this planet, they do the simple activities like gardening also with full enthusiasm, they arenâ€™t spending their retirement resting on an arm chair instead they attend Karaoke nights, indulge in group activities, sell their produce in vegetable market and believe in eating simple and exercising.They live in present and enjoy every moment happily. Because being aware of the impermanence of things does not have to make us sad; it should help us love the present and those who surround us.'ðŸ¦‹Our Ikigai is different for all of us but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning. There is no perfect strategy of connecting with our ikigai. But what we learned from the Okinawans is that we should not worry too much about finding it. Like the author said â€œLife is not a problem to be solved. Just remember to have something that keeps you busy doing what you love while being surrounded by the people who love youâ€. The simplest things are often the most beautiful, and this book is the perfect example of this statement. ' Eat right, exercise, and do what makes you happy'...by following this motto, we can definitely find our 'ikagai', our reason to live.

text: Ikigai came to me at a moment when I was feeling distracted and lost from my ultimate goal. Also, I really feel sad to see my 75 plus mom in law and 65 plus mom to see sticking to bed and complaining that they are good for nothing now. I donâ€™t want to be one of these old women who canâ€™t rejoice life anymore, I wish to have both mental and physical strength in my old age too thatâ€™s why I have entertained Yoga to my daily routine.The book starts with Japanese proverb â€œOnly staying active will make you want to live a hundred yearsâ€ and it touches the art of staying young while growing old and also shares antiaging secrets. It also recommends to find flow in everything you doand master longevity. It gives a comparison of logotherapy of psychotherapy and prefers the previous. Apart from that, the book also tells the experience tales of centenarians as how they made it upto living longer and healthier life. The diet and exercise carry an essential ingredient in a perfect recipe of life.â€œNana Korobi Ya Oki/ Fall seven times, rise eightâ€ is the key to remain antifragile and be resilient to deal with the setbacks. Follow the philosophies of Budhism and Stoicism which aim at practicing well being while you are enjoying lifeâ€™s pleasures. According to stoicism, we should be able to control our emotions and curb our ego and negative emotions.I even loved the â€˜wabi sabiâ€™ and â€˜ichi-go ichi-eâ€™ concepts which tell us that instead of looking for beauty in perfection, we should look out beauty in the given things-the things  that are incomplete and temporary.Although the content on Yoga is something I just skipped because these were known facts and considerations.On the whole, Ikigai is a beautiful gift to the society. It leads you from darkness to light and follow a right path to healthy lifestyle. Worry less, Walk an extra mile and Weigh your burdens less. A good diet and some sort of exercise is needed to be added. Above all, everyone must have some purpose in life. It is the reason to live â€˜ikigaiâ€™ and not anything else,  which keeps you going. The authors Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles stress on never retire policy so as to stay young inside.

title: Simple yet magnificent!

text: I started reading Ikigai, the book by Hector Garcia and Frances Mirales. It is a really short book but so profound when it comes to the real reason why Okinawans from Japan live the longest. They are called super centenarian. They eat about 18 varieties of food every day, the move a lot basically do a lot of gardening and walk and lot of community work, and drink a special kind of tea made from local fruit. They also do radio taiso exercise of basically five minutes. More importantly, the book talks about doing what you love to do. When you are one with your activity and your concentration is high that means you are in flow and very few people can do that - to maintain the flow is the challenge. It is basically all that you give to a given moment whether you do yoga, or look after a baby, cook for your family, nurture your plants... you are one with that moment and that if you repeatedly do, that gets you in flow. The book is full of interesting examples that keep you turning the page and in my case swiping left. I really enjoyed the book which is essentially about how to stay in the flow in the given moment and such a fun read.

Best ones:- Never RETIRE. (If you have recently retired parents who are grumpy & throw tantrums, give them this book)- Stop eating JUST when you are about to get full. â€œHara hachi bu" means something like â€œFill your belly to 80 percent.â€- SLEEEEEP!!! Top models sleep a lot!- How to handle thoughts, emotions, BOREDOM. Vietnamese monk Thich Nhat Hanh, who would say, â€œHello, solitude. How are you today? Come, sit with me, and I will care for you.â€- A list of different Japanese meditations & practices.- The Pomodoro Technique to FOCUS : Get yourself a kitchen timer & commit to working on a single task as long as itâ€™s running.If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.

text: HÃ©ctor Garca and Francesc Miralles' book "Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life" explores the idea of "ikigai," a Japanese philosophy of discovering one's purpose and meaning in life.The writers offer insights into the fundamental ideas of ikigai, such as finding delight in everyday pleasures, being present in the moment, and strengthening a feeling of community and connection with others. They do this by drawing on their experiences in Japan and interviews with Japanese people.The book provides a road map for readers to find their own ikigai and lead a more contented, joyful life through interesting anecdotes and helpful suggestions. However, in order to get the most out of our current moment, we must also look to the future and plan our long-term goals. The writers stress how crucial it is to find harmony and balance in all facets of life, including work.

text: We all want to lead a long and healthy life. Donâ€™t we? Ikigai has all the elements to decode it. Ikigai is a Japanese word, translates to â€œ the happiness of always being busy or engagedâ€.  The people of Okinawa live a simple outdoor life, drink green tea, and eat a healthy diet served in a special bowl that limits to their eating. The book explains that every being has an Ikigai, a journey of self-discovery and itâ€™s worth the search. Ikigai draws attention to the lifestyle of Japanese people showcasing how they lead an optimal healthy life, filled with happiness, and longevity. The main focus is on diet, daily activities and a sense of joy. It also includes wisdom from supercentenarians(above the age of 110) from all over the world.Every individual's Ikigai is different but the search is common. Still searching for you Ikigai, no worries, smile, take a long breath and find one. Iâ€™m all praises for this book and cannot stop gushing about it. Grab it today.

title: Book quality is super good ðŸ‘

text: The book does a decent job of relating the concept of Ikigai to modern day psychology (with Frankl's Logotherapy from Man's Search for Meaning among others) and a few scientific references in a simple manner. It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a man's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself. It also tackles some ways to 'find your flow' and ensure that what you do receives 100% of your attention and that you enjoy whatever you are creating.The book also discusses certain other Japanese concepts like takumi (specialized workers) and moai (connections with community or friend-circle). The brief discussions have the benefit of being to the point and simple but also pose the risk of trivializing them into regular self-help advice. The book also delves into Japanese perspectives on living life and persevering without getting caught up in artificially-created urgency. But again, maybe the authors wished for the readers to research more or meditate more on the content given the concise treatment of the same.The chapters on diet and exercises have more details and thus, may be more useful. Certain foods are dealt with in greater detail as is the concept of 'hara hachi bu' wherein one eats only 80% of what would actually assuage his hunger. The chapter on exercises includes illustrations and steps. While they may suffice for some of the purposes mentioned in the book - the philosophy behind them, progressive increments and other essential details are missing or insufficient.I was interested in the concept of Ikigai and wanted to read more about it. Despite being well-written and presenting modern applications, the book did not fulfill my requirements at all. Some of the condensed content made me think that the extended research, including on-site interviews, done by the authors for writing this book was clearly lost in translation or presentation in certain parts.The hardcover is pretty and soothing with its matte texture. Inner pages are smooth and heavy with a cream tinge. The font size is good. The spine as well as pages hold up well. Overall, the book is quite light and sturdy. Bought it for INR 460 against MRP of INR 499.

text: A cleverly marketed book with a catchy cover that opens your pocket easily...But having read it, i must say that the content and the treatment of the theme or subject is very shallow. For a naive reader the material may appear nice with a diverse variety of Japanese terms sprinkeled all over. References to a whole lot of thinkers, writers adds to the charm.But the whole plot falls apart when it leaves youbwanting for more. This book is like a buffet of tiny little dishes from multiple cuisines. You get to sample them but thats it.Some examples cited are also ridiculous, for instance, the authir says that for years after the 2011 Tsunami that devastated Japan, the market boomed for Japanese construction companies. That according to the author makes those companies "anti-fragile", meaning something that gets stronger when harmed.  I dont get it at all. The tsunami did no direct harm to the construction companies so one is unable to appreciate how they got stronger after the calamity.If an occasional sprinkle of terms like Wabi-Sabi, Ichi-go, Ichi-e, hari-hachi-bu, mabui, tai chi, qigong and so on excite you - pick it up.The book really leaves you craving for more, an experience like when you order a full meal but are served small portions as if it was a side dish.

text: First the good part - chapter IX on â€˜Anti-fragilityâ€™, which discuss stoicism and similar Buddhist teachings are the best parts of the book. Already well known (to me), but nice to be reinforced about those principles. The epilogue nicely summarises the entire premise of the book.The bad part  the book are those sections which seems to promote pseudo-science when it comes to discussing diet and the benefits of certain types of food items. I will be the last person to take those things by face value. Also, the book described the lifestyle of the centenarians as if they were living that way their whole life (singing, dancing, tending to their garden), which is simply not true. I was more interested in knowing how they lead their earlier years - the young adult and Middle Ages - because that is where the key to longevity lies (not only in how they spent their old age).

Read through the case studies ranging from the German Concentration Camp to the life histories of Bill Gates and Einstein. text: I found it more like a wellness blog. I bought this book after coming across the IKIGAI venn diagram shared in an online session about life's purpose. The diagram explores 4 vocational elements namely what you love, what you are good at, what the world needs and what can be paid for. The idea is to choose a career that qualifies on these 4 elements. I bought the book to explore more about this concept. But the book is not about the diagram, it is about general principles of a happy and long life that are practiced in a small town Okinawa in Japan. It is a good read but my expectation were a lot more. I later did some search and came across this link that says the the creator of the diagram is not even a Japanese and had only listened to a ted talk about IKIGAI. This is a weird world. Anyway, can't discredit the book, it is a good read but know that it is not about the diagram that helps you choose a right career.

title: â¤ï¸

text: Author and aspirant philosopher Hector Gracia was born in Spain. He has spent the past 18 years in Japan. Before moving to Japan, he was a software engineer in Switzerland. His most notable books are Ikigai, A Nerd in Japan, and Ichigo Ichie.Fiction, self-help, and inspirational works by award-winning author Francesc Miralles, who was also born in Spain. He concentrated on news-casting, English writing, and German. He has likewise filled in as a manager, interpreter, professional writer, and artist. His book Ikigai and Love in Lowercase made him famous.The creators of Ikigai have talked with many centenarians of Japan to unwind their mystery of being youthful and cheerful, at a late stage in life. The majority of Japanese lived on Okinawa, a Japanese island where 24 out of every 100,000 people are over 100 years old, significantly more than the global average. There are fewer diseases and longer lifespans among Okinawan women than anywhere else in the world. Lessons in the book are based on how these Japanese centenarians treat their work and their way of life, as well as what they eat and drink.The book presents the idea of ikigai and how it assists the Japanese nation with carrying on with a sound life late in the game. The authors then talk about how to prevent aging and how stress can harm our health. Case studies in which individuals discovered their purpose and concepts of logotherapy are discussed. Additionally, the fundamental tenets of Morita Therapy are discussed. The authors describe flow, the three steps that can be taken to achieve flow in the workplace, and how flow can help you discover your ikigai in the following chapter.The philosophy, routines, lifestyle, and diet of Japanese centenarians are discussed in the following chapters. Then the book makes sense of a few yoga and activities of Japanese individuals which keeps them solid. The idea of resilience and antifragility, which can help you deal with challenges in life without breaking down, is discussed in the final chapter. The ten ikigai rules are included in an epilogue at the book's conclusion.Three key examples which I have gained from the book is as per the following-(1)"Ikigai" is a Japanese word that implies a justification behind living, an importance for living. Having a clear purpose that makes our lives worthwhile is called having an ikigai. Your ikigai is something you enjoy doing, such as sleeping, scrolling Instagram, or watching Netflix. won't count), you can be paid for, you are good at, and the world needs you. For instance, if you enjoy singing a lot and are skilled at it, singing is probably your ikigai. You can get paid to write good songs because the world needs them.Therefore, the first step is to identify your ikigai, or purpose, and then you should constantly act in order to achieve this goal. The good news is that this action will make you feel satisfied, so it won't be boring. You won't ever feel lost if you have an Ikigai, a clear goal."He who has a for what reason to live for can endure with practically in any case."-Viktor Frankl, an Austrian nervous system specialist(2)Work with the streamWe as a whole have encountered a circumstance in our lives where we forgot about time. It could have been when you were reading a book and got so absorbed in it that you didn't realize how quickly three hours passed. In any case, there are additionally times when the inverse occurs, and time doesn't elapse by any means. This probably happened to you during a dull lecture. What is causing this distinction? Why does time pass more slowly when we engage in activities that we find distasteful than when we engage in activities that we find interesting?The solution is flow. Ta-dah! Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, a psychologist, coined the term flow and defined it as the pleasure we experience when we completely immerse ourselves in something. As per him,The state wherein individuals are so engaged with a movement that essentially nothing else appears to have any significance; Because it's so enjoyable, people will do it even if it costs a lot just for the thrill of it.At the point when we are in a condition of stream, we center around our work and not on interruptions. The power of center prompts Profound Work which builds our efficiency and simultaneously gives fulfillment. The work will be enjoyable once we find our flow.(3) Be resilient Being resilient was the most important lesson I took away from the book Ikigai. The capacity to withstand harm without becoming weakened is what is meant by resilience. It entails accepting everything that life throws at us without placing blame on others, without becoming frustrated, and without becoming discouraged.When you have a clearly defined ikigai, you must pursue it regardless of the difficulty. You can't surrender regardless of whether things are not going as per your assumption. Resilience's significance emerges at that point. Strength is our capacity to manage difficulties. We will be able to overcome challenges with greater ease if we have greater resilience. Resilient individuals are adept at overcoming challenges without becoming discouraged. They adjust to changes and focus just on those things which they can change.What impressed me most about Ikigai?First and foremost, I liked the idea of ikigai and the ways in which our ikigai can assist us in leading meaningful lives. This changes everything. The book's most beautiful chapter discussed the idea of flow and how to experience it in our work. I made notes about this idea because I liked it so much. Additionally, I enjoyed the section in which the authors discussed resilience and anti-fragility.The book made me realize how important it is to slow down, be in the moment, and be thankful for every little thing in my life. I was able to live peacefully, make friends, and enjoy every moment thanks to this book. I'm not sure; Because the book is like magic, I realized that there is nothing to worry about and only happiness to be had. It made me happy after I read it.What didn't I like about Ikigai?I anticipated, prior to reading the book, that it would assist me in discovering my own ikigai and purpose. However, when I read it, I found that it doesn't contain a lot of data about finding ikigai, which frustrated me. The book offers tips on how to exercise and eat more vegetables, both of which are somewhat commonplace and can be found in any blog. These were the few things about the book that I didn't like.Is it worth reading Ikigai?Indeed, the book Ikigai merits perusing since it contains numerous strong and demonstrated ideas which can assist you with working on your approach to everyday life. It can assist you in discovering your purpose and realizing the value of a purposeful life. In the present unpleasant and quick moving world, we seldom get any chance to recuperate our body, brain, and soul. You can gain a better understanding of the significance of slowing down and staying in the now by reading this book. Ikigai can assist you in having fun and losing yourself in your work if you're feeling bored in life. This book contains meetings of Japanese centenarians, which would propel you to carry on with a straightforward existence with high reasoning. All of the lessons were very useful, and anyone can easily put them into practice and see amazing results.Who ought to examine Ikigai?The book Ikigai is a must-read for anyone who is dissatisfied with their work and frustrated, who is overworked and stressed out at work and barely live their life, who lacks a purpose in life and feels lost, who is discouraged by failures, or any combination of the aforementioned. This book can also help people who don't live a healthy life, like those who smoke, drink, or eat junk food. Ikigai can cause anybody to figure out the significance of carrying on with an intentional life. Anyone who wants to live a long, fulfilled, and happy life can benefit from reading this book.

text: "Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life" is a book that explores the concept of ikigai, a Japanese term that roughly translates to "a reason for being." The authors, HÃ©ctor GarcÃ­a and Francesc Miralles, present a guide for discovering and nurturing one's ikigai, which they suggest can lead to a more fulfilling and contented life.The book begins by examining the history and cultural context of ikigai, tracing its origins to the island of Okinawa, where residents have among the longest lifespans in the world. The authors suggest that the pursuit of one's ikigai can lead to a sense of purpose and fulfillment that is linked to improved health and longevity.The book is divided into sections that explore different aspects of discovering one's ikigai, including identifying one's passions, discovering one's strengths and weaknesses, and finding ways to use one's skills and talents to benefit others. Throughout, the authors offer practical advice and exercises to help readers apply these concepts in their own lives.One of the strengths of the book is its focus on practicality. The authors provide concrete examples and exercises that readers can use to begin uncovering their own ikigai, and they encourage experimentation and exploration in the pursuit of a fulfilling life. The book is also well-written and engaging, with personal anecdotes and insights that make it an enjoyable read.However, some readers may find the book overly simplistic or superficial in its treatment of complex issues such as finding purpose and meaning in life. Additionally, some of the advice offered may not be applicable or relevant to all readers, depending on their individual circumstances.Overall, "Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life" is a well-written and engaging exploration of the concept of ikigai and its potential benefits for leading a fulfilling life. While some readers may find it overly simplistic or not entirely applicable to their own lives, others may find it a useful guide for uncovering their own sense of purpose and meaning.

text: I struggle to understand how this book has such great reviews. It barely scratches the surface of the concept of "Ikigai", and is full of "wikihow" style (i.e. superficial) explanations of several health and fitness ideas. There is no depth to any of the content, and the authors seem to be content with cramming in several loosely related concepts, rather than imparting some unique insight. That said, the book is really nice looking and feels wonderful in the hand, 5 stars to the printers!

text: Ikigai is a Japanese concept that means your 'reason for being. ' 'Iki' in Japanese means 'life,' and 'gai' describes value or worth.The book Ikigai is all about finding your life's purpose. It is about striking the balance between passion, profession, mission and vocation. This in turn leads to happiness and longevity. In many ways I felt the book reaffirms our learnings from Viktor Frankl's Man's Search For Meaning. Somehow, I felt the latter part of the book can be skipped as it is a jumble of things we come across in various other books. Even though the book in many places is redundant and repetitive, it has many nice takeaways from it.Of these I loved the Ten Rules of Ikigai which pretty much summarize the Ikigai way of life:â˜‘ï¸Stay active.â˜‘ï¸Don't retireâ˜‘ï¸Take it slowâ˜‘ï¸Get in shapeâ˜‘ï¸Live in the momentâ˜‘ï¸Reconnect with natureâ˜‘ï¸ Smileâ˜‘ï¸Surround yourself with good friendsâ˜‘ï¸Give thanksâ˜‘ï¸Follow your Ikigai

text: In the middle of me reading and enjoying this book, I recommended it to a cousin who's having doubts on herself in her new job, and some amount of anxieties about getting older. She replied with evident apathy, saying she'd had enough reading similar books, implying her doubt this book wouldn't be different. I have to admit there are many concepts, facts, and quotes we might have heard many times from consuming other sources before, but Miralles and Garcia offer invaluable new insights that stretch wide, that would inspire us to keep trying to be a better person, and eventually to live life to the fullest by having a purpose. A unique and real one that we've had since birth, that we're meant to discover if we haven't. Rather than becoming apathetic after my cousin's comment, I finished this book feeling really grateful for this book having found me, and getting even more convinced I won't stop reading self-help and inspiring books, because everyone needs a reminder every now and then anyway.

text: I am thanking Kindle Unlimited for sending my way all the good and powerful books. I happened to finish this one in 40 minutes. No, I wasn't counting time while reading it but the book is very short and takes you to the journey of self discovery. I knew about this book for long as I have always seen it in the collection of street vendors. But reading it along with appropriate examples was an enthralling experience. The biggest thing I wanted to learn was a difference between happiness and joy and this book made me believe that I have been more joyful than happy. I accept it by now. Also, it talks about finding the true purpose in life. I hope you all find yours as I have found mine and it is keeping me on the right track of penning my world into words.

title: Good product

text: This book is the result of the authors' attempt to unlock the secrets of the extraordinary longevity of the Japanese , especially in the island of Okinawa , where you can find 24.55 centenarians per 100,000 inhabitants , far above the global average . The authors feel that such longevity cannot be explained only by  a healthy diet , a simple life in the open ,green tea and the sub-tropical climate. According to them , it is the Japanese term , ikigai , roughly translated as the happiness of always being busy  or a reason to jump out of bed early morning , which may be specific to each individual  that has contributed to such a long life , mostly free from chronic and debilitating diseases so common in advanced age elsewhere. When they explore the concept further with the centenarians through interviews and participation in their daily lives , they come across other traits arising from their ikigai , viz going with the flow , focus on the present , prioritization, staying active beyond retirement , enjoying mundane tasks , resilience or ' anti-fragility ' ( getting stronger when harmed ) while facing the misfortunes of life etc. In addition , their lifestyle involving a fruit and vegetable diet along with fish , low sugar and salt intake , lot of walking or moving , an active social and community life ,gardening , regular calisthenics - all these contribute to a happy and long life. The book is definitely a readable  and compact contribution to gerontology , though we may find certain parts a bit repetitive.
date: Reviewed in India ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ on 5 May 2022
title: A compact explanation of ikigai , the Japanese secret to long life

text: I live and work in Japan. Was very surprised to see a book on Ikigai and â€œ secret of Japanâ€ etc. I have no complaints against the book which is incidentally written by non Japanese authors but Japan suffers from one of the highest suicide rates in the world and depression is the most common disease in Japan. So much so that one can take indefinite leave from work if depressed and still be fully paid for it as per Japanese legal system.Point is the concept that Japanese society is in â€œIkigaiâ€ state is misleading and false. This book is selling a false concept.

text: I have always wondered about the Japanese spirit of resilience and rebirth. How do they live so long? How are they so productive to the end of their days? How do they have such excellent physiques? Most importantly, what gives them the tenacity to never give up even in the face of the most extreme odds (the aftermath of the WW2 being an example, out of which the Japanese only came out stronger)?The answer is in this book, and it is Ikigai.Ikigai doesn't just preach; it peppers itself with several examples and anecdotes, including tips from the supercentenarians of the world (those who have lived beyond 110 years). It gives thorough advice on enriching various aspects of life.I strongly recommend this book to all of us who are still looking for meaning in our lives, who feel that life is out to get them at every moment, who are, simply, too overwhelmed by everything that's going on around. Do pause awhile, and immerse yourself in this world of Ikigai and you'll come out richer.And, since I heard the audiobook on Audible, I'd put a word of recommendation for that too. Brilliantly narrated, with the right pauses and inflections and the calls to action.

text: Our ikigai is different for all of us, but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning.â€â€• Hector Garcia PuigcerverThe word 'IKIGAI' is a Japanese concept which means "a reason for being". It refers that one must have a purpose in life which will make their life worthwhile, and for this one must take some willing actions to feel satisfied and have some meaning to life.This book mainly tells that every single person has their own ikigai. Every person finds an ikigai at a certain point of life. Our ikigai is different from others and is hidden deep inside us. Once a person discovers his or her ikigai, it brings meaning to their lives. It is not like that a person has no meaning of living. The books  notifies various methods using which a person can find their purpose in life. A person can find their purpose by doing different activities till they don't feel cheerful and pleased doing it.So far as liking this book, it was good. It had some motivational lessons to improve our lives. Also had some ways following which one could refine lives. But the way it was written did not have much impact on me as every chapter till the end had same things repeated in different ways. It is a bit overrated!

text: Ikigai - The Japanese Secret to long and happy life.The book touches various aspects of life which can help us achieve a long and better life. Basically, it beautifully explains the deep art of staying young while growing old. Various real-life examples are cited, especially with reference to Okinawa, a Japanese island inhabiting people with higher life expectancy.It is quite evident that the authors stress more on discovering the meaning of life rather than creating one for you. Most importantly, the book helps us in finding the meaning of being in the 'flow' and how to achieve the 'flow'.The book concludes after introducing another Japanese Technique called â€” Wabi-Sabi - finding beauty in imperfect, incomplete things. Here flawed is preferred over perfection. Japanese believe that only imperfect, incomplete and ephemeral things are beautiful because they resemble the nature.To conclude, I think the book reading experience was as beautiful as the book cover. It can be read in just 4 hours as it only has around 200 pages. But those 4 hours can be life altering and the readers have high chances of keeping the teachings of this book in their mind for very long.

text: About the book ðŸ“–: â—¾The word ikigai is derived from iki, meaning "life" or "alive" and kai, meaning "worth" or "benefit". They combined term ikigai make it as "meaning or purpose".â—¾Essentials to happiness in this life are something to do, something to love, and something to hope for.â—¾Our ikigai is different for all of us, but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning.â—¾Life is not a problem to be solved. Just remember to have something that keeps you busy doing what you love while being surrounded by the people who love you.â—¾Life is not a problem to be solved.â—¾Walk slowly and youâ€™ll go far. When we leave urgency behind, life and time take on new meaning.â—¾A positive attitude and a high degree of emotional awareness are the keys for longevity.â—¾Our ability to turn routine tasks into moments of micro flow, into something we enjoy, is key to our being happy, since we all have to do such tasks.â—¾Artists know how important it is to protect their space, control their environment, and be free of distractions. â—¾There is a passion inside you, a unique talent that gives meaning to your days and drives you to share the best of yourself until the very end. If you donâ€™t know what your ikigai is yet, as Viktor Frankl says, your mission is to discover it.â—¾ Resilience and Wabi-Sabi: To face life's challenges without letting stress and worry age you. â—¾Our intuition and curiosity are very powerful internal compasses to help us connect with our ikigai.

text: Ikigai, means, 'a reason for living; a meaning for life; what makes life worth living; a raison d'Ãªtre'.The book elucidates the importance of "finding and living with purpose."It also explains many concepts:-> the importance of eating a balanced diet,> practicing and achieving mindfulness, being conscious of daily routine, being goal oriented, managing stress and living a stress-free life, having a positive outlook and a high degree of emotional awareness,> Logotherapy: Discovering life's purpose, accepting or rejecting destiny, and finding new passion for life which will help you to overcome obstacles and sorrows.> Morita therapy: Accepting emotions, focusing on the present, Asking yourselfâ€“'What do we need to be doing right now?What action should we be taking?, and creating new emotions on the basis of actions.> Finding flow in everything you do. Concentrating on one thing at a time may be the single most important factor in achieving flow. Training the mind through meditation can get us to a place of flow.> Microflowâ€“Enjoying mundane, routine & repetitive tasks.> Meaningful and inspiring statements of Japan's centenarians: Don't worry, Cultivate good habits, Nurture your friendships everyday, Live an unhurried life and Be optimistic.> Doing low-intensity simple exercises such as Radio taiso, Yoga, Tai chi, Qigong, Stretching and breathing exercises.> Pursuing passion and never giving up on it. Developing resilience. A Japanese proverb says, Fall seven times, rise eight. Getting rid of things such as certain types of food, people, habits etc.,  that make you fragile.> Practicing emotional resilience with the aim of curbing our ego and controlling our negative emotions.The author mentions ten rules that have been distilled from the wisdom of the long-living residents of Ogimi, Japan:(1) Stay active;don't retire(2) Take it slow: Not to be in a hurry. When we live urgency behind, life and time take on new meaning.(3) Don't fill your stomach: Follow the 80 percent rule(4) Surround yourself with good friends(5) Get in shape for your next birthday(6) Smile(7) Reconnect with nature(8) Give thanks(9) Live in the moment(10) Follow your ikigaiThe author says â€“ Ikigai is different for all of us, but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning. Once you discover your Ikigai, pursuing it and nurturing it every day will bring meaning to your life.In my opinion, everyone should read this book many times till these concepts are memorized and put into practice. Highly recommended.

title: Ikigai

text: In a bid to simplify my overtly success-loaded, busy, rapid-fire life, I had lifted this book off a mall in Delhi, mostly out of desperation for liberation.Every day I practiced the art of the flow as stated in the book---being in the flow with whatever it is that you are doing so that you become one with the work---and slowly and steadily changes began infiltrating my life.I wrote a poem as a way to describe flow in writing (this is something hardcore writers will relate to):"This desire arises whenever I write,And am undesirous of the slightest respite,A non-existent realm beyond the logicalâ€™s sight,This world the rational forever pleads to bite.This realm exists so we, writers, never die,A spotless sea so lucid you could really cry,No inhibitions, praises and critics we bid goodbye,Where we will always be and never need to try.Because thatâ€™s what we are and have always been,Immortal yes, this realm does exist for I have seen,So while you folks measure our worth being mean,We travelled miles away and expand into the unseen."(The title of the poem I had given as "Could I be Immortal?)Flow is a state where you are inseparable from that which you are involved in. Once in this state, you work at your best, and experience bliss.  In the state of flow you dont experience ay resistance whatsoever and hence you experience an eternity and the desire for immortality for contemplative minds like mind could be a natural result!the book speaks about the researched lives and way of living of the largest number of centenarians in the world---ie. in Japan. What they eat, how they live everyday, the way they think, how they live minimalistic lives and sink into a state of flow in their pursuits, foods they refrain from and spiritual practices they practise daily.Powerful book for people wanting to simplify their lives! Please go ahead and buy the boy! It isn't the usual kind of self-help books that you would wish to push aside. text: ðŸ’—" Being aware of the impermanence of things does not have to make us sad; it should help us love the present and those who surround us".ðŸIn today's busy and stressful world, it can be very difficult to find your 'ikagai'- your reason to start your day with smile by doing things which you love. But there are people in this world, who are over a hundred years, who are active, and happy, doing what they love. In this book, author talks about living active, stress-free , happy life by sharing real life experiences of people..â£ï¸Ikigai is a Japanese concept, which means â€œthe happiness of always being busy". It explains the extraordinary longevity of the Japanese, especially on the island of Okinawa.It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a everyone's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself.The book touches the various aspects of life which can help us achieve a long happy life.It also talks about diets, yoga, exercise ,some therapies like logotherapy, Morita therapy and about how stress affects our body and mind..ðŸŒ¿What I loved about the book is a reiteration of FACTS that we all know. We can try to implement them in out day to day lifestyle.ðŸ€ Never RETIRE --Keep doing things of value, helping out and shaping the world aroundYou,even after your 'official' activity ended..ðŸ€Take it slow- No Multitasking.Research says that concentrating on one thing at a time may be the single most factor in achieving flow..ðŸ€Dont fill your stomach - â€œHara hachi bu" means something like â€œFill your belly to 80 percent.â€ðŸ€Surround yourself with friends, smile more , reconnect with nature and always live in the moment..ðŸ€Start your work session with a ritual you enjoy and end with a reward...ðŸŒ¼The language is very simple and understandable. The graphical representations of yoga and Radio Taiso are very nice. Epilogue and notes are making book more interesting. The experiences shared by the people are very encouraging and motivational.

title: Nice read

text: I recently completed reading a very inspiring book â€” IKIGAI â€” The Japanese Secret to a Long Happy Life. The book is authored by Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles. In this article, I am going to talk about my learning from the book.The book touches the various aspects of life which can help us achieve a long happy life. It is based on ancient, well practised Japanese technique called â€” IKIGAI.If you google the word, you will get various meanings like-A reason for being, encompassing joy, a sense of purpose and meaning and a feeling of well-beingORThe word derives from iki, meaning life and kai, meaning the realisation of hopes and expectations.But the one I liked the most is â€”A reason to jump out of bed each morning!This book draws a lot of references from an island in Japan called â€” Okinawa where there 24.5 inhabitants of age more 100 for every 1,00,000 people.book explains how stress, a lot sitting adds up to your age and makes reduces your life duration. Interesting it also mentions very prominently that little stress is good for you since it keeps you going. I firmly believe â€” Being Conscious of Your Daily Routine Can Lead to A Better Life!it helps you deep dive into discovering the meaning of your life. It is quite evident that the authors stress more on discovering the meaning of life rather than creating one for you!This part is my most favourite where the authors helps you find the meaning of being in the flow. If you have discovered the meaning of your life, you need to completely immerse into the experience without being distracted by the surroundings and you attain the flow.There are several more techniques like wabi sabi..This techniques talks about finding beauty in imperfect, incomplete things. Here flawed is preferred over perfection. Japanese believe that only imperfect, incomplete and ephemeral things are beautiful because they resemble the nature.To conclude, I think the book is extremely inspiring and full of content. I could attain my flow while reading it. Loved it ! Highly recommended reading â€” You can buy the book on Amazon!Hope it was helpful.Thanks for reading.

text: Quote from the book:"Only staying active will make you want to live a hundred years."Food for thought:The first thought that pops up in a conversation regarding this book is the title. Ikigai translates into an abstract form of expression unbound by "the happiness of always being busy."The concept and philosophy of longevity are drawn from the Okinawa tribe in Japan. The fact that the majority number of centenarians hails from their humble abode leaves one confounded. The Village of Longevity, as it's rightly called, has its allure in its simple living and minimalistic instincts.As we embark upon the mission to find our ikigai, there are snippets of facts that can hold one's attention far longer than one would expect from a self-help book. The interwoven display of our very own being is primary and easy to understand.It is a book like no other! You will be exercising not only your mind and body but also your spirit.Ikigai has redefined my consciousness and revealed the pure bliss of living. Let not fear crinkle your eyes or stress wrinkle your foreheads. The true spirit of the book is in its lucid language and beautiful analogies.There is a sense of calm and acceptance that flows throughout the book. Holistic living and mindfulness are essential for making conscious decisions. Prudent choices leave an impact more prominent than any force trying to shape our tomorrow.Disclaimer:It will anchor your thoughts and ground your feelings.My favorite part of the book is anecdotes from the people who live to be 110 years of age or more. I was stumped by the stories and couldn't believe it at first glance. The proof was right there in their recounted tales as I kept gaping at the pages in disbelief.

text: "Ikigai" is a wonderful book that delves into the Japanese concept of "ikigai," which translates to "the reason for being." The authors, Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles, do an excellent job of exploring the history and philosophy behind ikigai, and provide practical tips for readers to find their own ikigai.The book is divided into several chapters, each of which explores a different aspect of ikigai. The authors cover topics such as mindfulness, purpose, passion, and community, and provide numerous examples of how people have found their ikigai in various ways.One of the strengths of "Ikigai" is its accessibility. The authors write in a clear, concise style that is easy to understand, and they provide plenty of anecdotes and examples to illustrate their points. Additionally, the book is visually appealing, with beautiful illustrations and photographs throughout.Overall, I highly recommend "Ikigai" to anyone interested in exploring the concept of ikigai and finding more purpose and happiness in their lives. The book is well-written, informative, and inspiring, and is sure to leave readers feeling motivated to discover their own reason for being.

text: ðŸ’ŒFavourite line: "Everything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedomsâ€”to choose oneâ€™s attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose oneâ€™s own way."..ðŸ“– In this book, the term ikigai is translated as the bliss of always being busy. Ikigai is actually a combination of your passion, your mission and your profession. this book answers some basic questions as to why some people tirelessly keep doing what they have been doing for years tirelessly even though it's the same things over and over again, say, actors, writers, bloggers, artists and so on. Why do some people never get bored or frustrated repeating doing the same things over and over again?â›„Now I know this book is overhyped in the market and a lot of us have too high expectation from it. While I think the book is more about answering the basic question which we most of the time overlook. Also, it provides a ten-point compressed rule of ikigai:Stay active; donâ€™t retire.Take it slow.Donâ€™t fill your stomach.Surround yourself with good friends.Get in shape for your next birthday.SmileReconnect with nature.Give thanks.Live in the moment.Follow your ikigai...âœ¨Overall, this book is truly uplifting. The reader is intrigued by the simplicity and calming tone it offers, and it captures the attention of the reader till the end. The book unleashes the Japanese Zen philosophy, inspiring the readers to search and discover.

text: Review IkigaiIkigai, a book that was on my list for long, I got an audio book as I was not getting much time to sit and read, well it was very nice to listen it through. I might have enjoyed more reading it but I had to complete it as it was stacking on my list from many months. I would suggest the audio book for those who have a keen hearing sense and not multi task while listening.About the book, it is too hard to write something about Ikigai, but it sure teaches are a lot of things and tells us of many interesting facts. The place in Okinawa which is called the place of Longevity, the people and their typical style of living, something that impressed me the most. Well, the whole book is worth reading, and learning from.There are certainly few things that are easy to follow, like the 80% eating habit, walk in the nature, no Tech days, walking â€“ keep moving, friends, smiling and having a hobby that keeps you busy otherwise. In all those we can always find our Ikigai, once we find one, just follow the flow. I do not mean to say that oneâ€™s Ikigai is one among these but with these you can always get inside your self to find what is it, for you.TH 10 principles towards the end of the book are really helpful and easy to understand and not very easy to follow thou. What I really want to try is the White Tea thou. Another interesting thing is the village in Okinava where the youngest man, was about 83 years old, most of the people are around 100. Some of the inputs from the people who lived more than 100 were good to hear, not sure if it is so easy to follow though.On the whole a wonderful book, and I sure will read this book some other time and see what is that I can adopt, if not for longevity but for piece of mind which is much needed for everyone in todayâ€™s techno-busy world.

text: Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life" by Hector Garcia is a fascinating book that explores the concept of "ikigai" â€“ the Japanese concept of finding one's purpose in life. The book delves into the secrets of the world's longest-living people, the residents of the Japanese island of Okinawa, who have discovered the key to a long and happy life.The author provides a comprehensive overview of the concept of ikigai, which is essentially the intersection of one's passion, mission, vocation, and profession. The book is divided into several chapters that explore the different aspects of ikigai, including finding joy in everyday life, living in the present moment, and cultivating strong relationships.What makes this book unique is that it draws on the insights of the residents of Okinawa, who have a reputation for living long and healthy lives. Through interviews and case studies, the author reveals the secrets of their longevity, which include a plant-based diet, regular exercise, and a strong sense of community.The writing style of the book is engaging and easy to follow, making it accessible to a wide range of readers. The author includes plenty of real-life examples and practical tips for readers to implement in their own lives. The book is also beautifully illustrated, with stunning photographs of Okinawa and its inhabitants.Overall, "Ikigai" is a thought-provoking and inspiring book that encourages readers to reflect on their own lives and discover their own purpose. It provides practical insights and actionable advice for anyone who wants to live a long, healthy, and fulfilling life. I highly recommend this book to anyone who is interested in personal growth and self-discovery

text: The rather exotic sounding name of this book, ikigai, as the authors explain, is relatively straightforward. â€œThis Japanese concept, which translates roughly as â€œthe happiness of always being busy,â€ is, â€œlike logotherapy, but it goes a step beyond.â€ Logotherapy, they explain, â€œâ€¦helps people find their purpose in life.â€It is a good book. My overall rating of the book has little to do with the quality of the writing or the underlying concept. The former is quite good and the latter is valid. My rating is strictly personal and relates more to who might be considering adding it to their reading list. Not a â€œdonâ€™t,â€ for sure. More like, â€œunderstand it for what it is.â€For those who are ardent fans of all things philosophical and psychological, as I am, this is a good book that plows relatively little new ground. Finding purpose in life, keeping busy, eating well, and finding connection to the world around you is important. Itâ€™s ground, however, that has been covered by many authors over the years.If you havenâ€™t sampled of these past triumphs you will enjoy this book very much. It is a great and easily read introduction to the topics of longevity and the benefits of living in the moment. And it chronicles many of the philosophies and prior contributions to the topic, from Buddhism to Stoicism, with a stop at the Serenity Prayer. Eastern, and particularly Japanese, contributions are given extra attention. Wabi-sabi and ichi-go ischi-e, for example, are explained in some detail, but remain an overview. Relatively newer concepts like antifragility are also explained. It even covers the Six Healing Sounds introduced by Sun Simiao in the sixth century. (This one was new to me.)A lot of the book turns on Ogimi, in the Okinawa Prefecture in Japan, which holds the distinction of being the oldest village on the planet. (In that many of the residents have lived very long lives.) Itâ€™s a delightful visit. Having lived in China for nine years and having visited Japan many times over the course of more than three decades, I have a deep fondness for places like Ogimi. Iâ€™m not sure, however, that they arenâ€™t byproducts of the totality of Japanese culture. Could they take seed in places like California or Virginia, for example?Part of my ikigai is to be a nice person and not think disparagingly of anyone. And I am not here. This book was an interesting read for me, and may be a revelational read for you. I make no judgment on that. I just give you my experience as a reader.This book would, in my opinion, make an excellent gift for anyone in your life that might need a little boost or is otherwise hard to buy for. There is absolutely nothing here that could meet with controversy or resistance. It is decidedly upbeat throughout.And that is saying a lot of good things about any book.

text: Okay. So, I normally balk at purchasing self help books and try to find some other way of gleaning the often infinitesimally small bit of useful information that they actually impart. Free months on kindle unlimited etc.If this book has done one thing, it is to reinforce that rule and remind me not to be so foolish in the future.For those of you that are considering buying this book but do not want to waste precious time, sifting through the 95% of this book that is, bulking, waffle, irrelevant, endless repetition of the work Ikigai and theories as to why people on Okinawa live longer than most on the planet....** There are two things that you need to know.1. Write down the activities, hobbies, work, that you do, that make you happy (you are half way through the book before they ask you to do this!). Things that not only make you smile and feel fulfilled but where the time passes noticeably more quickly because you are focussed on the enjoyable task at hand.2. Incorporate those activities as much as you can in your daily life.The answers are pretty much in front of you on the Amazon web page for this book. Just take a look at the pictures provided and work it out for yourself from there. Itâ€™s not rocket science.Good luck and live a happy and long life with an extra Â£10 in your pocket. text: An interesting take on the meaning of life; the conundrum we exist. The Japanese elderly in Ogimi and Okinawa generally have life figured out. Smile, do light exercise, walk a little daily, eat well, enjoy herbal tea and smile as a part of a community. While this book might present the 'knowns' of what it takes to be happy it weaves in a philosophy of serenity to the chaos that is daily life for most people in the west. It shows us we can be happy in finding our own purpose in life and that living our own ikigai we can have a wholesome existence fulfilling human nature in combination with our own desires.I gave this book four stars simply because I think something is missing, something that addresses those big existential questions I always have trouble understanding. Who we are, where we come from and why we're here in the first place.While I didn't find my own Ikigai by reading this book it did help me realise I need to find it. The authors, Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles did a wonderful job of bringing some elderly wisdom to a world clearly in need. Worth every penny and a fluent comfortable read.If you're thinking about buying this stop thinking. Buy.

text: I found Ikigai extremely insightful.I had come across the term before in my reading and wanted to know more about the concept and with this book I got more than just and understanding of Ikigai. The book was a well curated guide to purpose, which is the essence of ikigai, it pulled together a lots of philosophical links to other concepts and thinkers, some of whom were new to me, which will lead to a lot of fun rabbit-holes to jump into!The book challenged my expectations I expected a very deep dive into one concept but actually discovered that ikigai isn't as simple as this. I found some sections of the book more meaningful than others, with a couple seeming a bit superficial, but this was probably more to do with the subject I had already read.I think if you new to philosophy and in particular Eastern philosophy this book is a fantastic first step, if you are a practicing some of the concepts in the book already you may find some of the detail a bit light.

text: The negative reviewers seem to have largely missed the point. Or to have been looking for something they will not find in a book. Yes there are chapters on diet and exercise, and the content of these is not particularly new or surprising (however irritating it may be, these things are indeed features of a healthy lifestyle).But there is a good deal more, including the sense of purpose and meaning that is common to those who have lived to an advanced age. The way this is explored and its links to, for example, logotherapy, are helpful and illuminating. Ikigai offers a genuine recipe for living a meaningful life if you are prepared to give it some time and thought.I strongly disagree with the reviewer who wanted it to be much longer! Most books are badly overwritten and in need of editing: the value of a book is in the quality of its content, not the number of pages it fills. This one is attractively presented, says what it needs to, then stops.

text: I purchased Ikigai: The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life because I wanted to learn about Ikigai and how I might go about identifying my personal Ikigai (i.e. raison d'etre, or "ultimate why". I was intrigued by the well-known Venn diagram used to illustrate the concept and was hoping to use it as a framework. In actual fact, there is no real discussion of this (despite it appearing on the back cover) and the only instruction given on how to identify your Ikigai is to list all the activities that get you into the "flow" state - a worthwhile exercise for sure, but that's only a starting point. On the plus side, the book is well written, beautifully typeset, and an easy read; however, the central topic is longevity, of which Ikigai is just one contributing factor. If you are interested in an overview of the Japanese approach to leading a long and happy life, then this book is for you. If you are specifically interested in finding your Ikigai, I suspect there are more useful resources out there.

text: If you've read Freakonomics, you'll see why.When talking about life expectancy authors rely heavily on interviews with long-living individuals to deduct the factors that contribute to their ability to live long. This is simply irrelevant. If you ask an average tall person, why they are tall, they would not be able to answer, and their ideas and intuition would be as good as yours.Authors have a very noble goal of finding the factors that increase one's life expectancy, but they do so without use of statistical analysis and or scientific methods often leading to humorous contradictions.Here's one example: "during last 100 years, life expectancy increased in average 0.3 years per year". "Cavemen had much less stress than modern humans, since volumes of information and devices are contributing to the stress". But why is then life expectancy growing proportionally to the development of media then? Maybe this informational stress *positively* correlates with life expectancy? Without proper research it is impossible to tell if values are correlated and if they have any reason-cause relations.I liked a chapter about author's experience in Ogimi in Okinawa was nevertheless very good. Not because the insights were valuable, but because of a vivid image of traditional Japan that authors have conveyed. This is the most authentic chapter and it deserves a separate book. I would read that book, not this one.Authors jump between subjects of mental health, having purpose in life, diet and exercise, compiling and reciting many other great books. From this perspective, the book was very valuable, since I learned about works of Nassim Nicholas Taleb and Viktor Frankl. I already knew about Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi and planned to read his book "Flow".Doing my own research on what authors have briefly mentioned I discovered several other areas of knowledge that I want to learn more about. This was the biggest value of this book.Lastly, authors start to jump over myriad of loosely-related subjects: diet and nutritions, meditation, spiritual practices, yoga, tai chi, and it all in just few words. Pictures of Tai Chi exercises together with the descriptive text looked like a waste of space in an already tiny book.I would not recommend to read the book, but instead read all the other books that this book borrowed ideas from.

text: Delivery and book state:- (â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… 5 stars)Delivery of this book was really quick and it came in a great state and giving 5 stars for seller.Book review:- (â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… 4 stars)â€œOnly staying active will make you want to live a hundred yearsâ€-Japanese proverbIkigai is a point where passion meets profession meets mission meets vocation.Japanâ€™s Okinawa island has the highest life expectancy in the world. Itâ€™s ikigai which contributes significantly in having a long and happy life, apart from their life style(especially diet and exercise routine).This book briefly explains the concept of Logotherapy (a branch of psychology which helps people find their purpose in life) and Ikigai is something similar to that, motivational force for everyday life.Ikigai is not something you can find just by reading this book overnight, you have to discover it patiently. Also this book is not exactly about how you can find your Ikigai; however, it offers various tips to find your own flow and ways to maintaining it. It has also explained contributing factors in longevity. On and all it was blissful read.
date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§ on 17 April 2020
title: Blissful read!

text: The authors seem to imply that a long, healthy life is synonymous with Ikigai; multiple chapters are spent discussing how to achieve a long, healthy life by lowering your stress, eating healthy, exercising, having meaningful relationships, ect. - things that are generally common sense. While these things are obviously important and can influence your ability to find your ikigai and remain in a peaceful state, I don't believe long life is synonymous with ikigai; the former is focused on longevity and the second on purpose. Furthermore, I would have liked more material that would actually guide readers towards thier ikigais instead of high-level overviews. The author ends with essentially saying to just follow your interests (while being healthy) and to not worry too much about finding your ikigai; I suppose the authors were suggesting to appreciate the journey rather than being fixated on the destination. Criticisms aside, there were a few good reminders in the book, and it was a short read, so I think reading this book was still a positive use of my time.

text: I loved the concept of IKIGAI when I first saw the diagram, and bought this book because I imagined it would help me through the process of mapping out and defining my IKIGAI. A kind of step-by-step guide to discovering my IKIGAI. It isn't that. About halfway through the book I realised it wasn't going to provide that level of insight and 'instruction', and initially felt disappointed. I stopped reading and decided to re-read the book for what it is, rather than from the perspective of what I expected it to be, and I discovered a wonderful book I definitely recommend for other seekers.It's filled with some great insights, brief introductions to other great philosophies, and a high-level overview of the 'territory' that includes IKIGAI. If you're looking for a detailed map with precise instructions on how to go from 'here' to 'there', this book is not going to be that for you. It is, instead, a very broad guide that points in the general direction of IKIGAI, and gives you some other IKIGAI-related nuggets of wisdom for consideration and inspiration.If you're feeling something tugging inside of you, this is a great place to start. If you're being pulled strongly in a specific direction and are seeking a comprehensive guide through the mist, this book may frustrate you rather than help you.
