text: Anyone interested in taking steps toward living a long and healthy life has probably already read, heard, or surmised 95% of the tips offered in this book. But the 5% that makes the difference is the part where the Ikigai comes in. Here in the west we all hear about how stress is killing us, and weâ€™re inundated with practices and techniques to alleviate it. Weâ€™re encouraged to be â€œmindfulâ€ but not much is forthcoming about how to be happy. And we donâ€™t hear so much about purpose or finding our reason to live (Ikigai). I think anyone who is not clinically depressed or on the brink of suicide would say â€œyesâ€ if asked, â€œWould you want to live to 110 years of age in perfect health, in a state of joy, with no need for assistance with any physical or mental task?â€ And in this book, there are scores of interviews with people doing exactly that. Ikigai shines the spotlight on the habits, approach to, and outlook on life that are most likely responsible for not just the longevity but the vigorous and joyful longevity of the people of Okinawa - lives filled with self-sufficiency, movement, gratitude, love, peace, and antifragility.

title: This Should Be In Every Library

text: I really enjoy the simple and easy reading, as if I was reading the authors journals from their search about Ikigai.And this is such an important theme and I'd suggest everyone should read about it or be more conscious about it, specially if you aren't living your passion. On a side note, this goes beyond having a passion in life (something we really enjoy doing) to how we can appreciate more life.However, this books feels like a collection of notes and topics at a very surface level. This topic is important but sometimes I wish there would be a place in publishing for articles, blog posts, or concepts that could be explained in a few pages. I liked reading this book but I feel it just doesn't deliver and let's me wonder which book should I actually read if I'd like to read more about the mix of topics it talks about. The book tries to be too many things and in the end is very shallow.And if I talk about longevity, then it's really weak. At minimum anecdotical as the lists and recommendations are just weakly researched and elaborated. It's probably a good overview but not more than that. Perhaps I should read the book about the blue zones.As the authors seem to be great at writing, as I said the text is easy and engaging to read, I wished they had focused more on one topic and delivered something more substantial.It's an OK book to introduce people on the topics around ikigai. I wouldn't say the same about longevity. A lot is common sense, just the majority doesn't do it. A lot is contextual, for instance, we know that community living is important and beneficial. However, our city life development and moving to other cities makes this more and more difficult. Not to mention the demands on today's jobs and their working hours.Despite all this, it's an inspirational book and I do hope it inspires many people to find their Ikigai and create a more community living setup around them.

text: First of all the Diagramm pictured on the back is NOT IKIGAI !It's from Andres Zuzunaga and has been spread as the Ikigai Venn Diagramm, which has nothing to do with Ikigai itself !I find it highly concerning that someone who 'researched' Ikigai did not know this or even though still included it....Now that I got the bad things out of the way let's talk about the book itself:The book itself isn't that bad and actually covers core components of Ikigai (and doesn't include the Diagramm)...It's easy and quick to read with some interesting parts.The physical book itself i have to say is gorgeous...Nice to the touch, beautiful design and feels high quality in general.To conclude this review this book is a nice and quick read and looks really good on a bookshelf (if that matters to you).But keep in mind the Diagramm is not Ikigai and let it theirfore not taint your understanding of it.

text: Leaning heavily on Dan Buettnerâ€™s Blue Zones, this book presents the 101 of longevity beyond Ikigai. It dabbles into nutrition, where it even mentions Dr Mosleyâ€™s 5:2 diet (and claims fasting â€œhelps cleanse the digestive systemâ€ - a notion that probably would make Valter Longo cringe) and professes benefits of melatonin produced at sleep that arenâ€™t the main health benefit of sleep (please read Prof Walker for that).In short: this book has no direction, is imprecise on the science and would have been better if it had staid focussed on Ikigai. The excursions into Japanese spirituality and logotherapy I found interesting - and probably less offensive as I have never read anything about these topics before.Rarely has a book made me so angry. Not only did I stop halfway in order not to waste my time further but I took the time to write this scathing review (I rarely write reviews and usually they are more flattering) to warn people.

text: I am a non-Japanese person who has lived in Japan for over 3 years, and was interested in this mystical concept of "ikigai". So, I thought I would start with this well-reviewed book.Despite it's title and introduction, this book touches very little on ikigai, and instead focuses on "how to live a long time" based on poorly researched information (the Daily Mirror said fruits are healthy, who knew!!!) and random, biased accounts of different forms of therapy, asian philosophy, and even *Chinese* tai-chi. The authors had the rare opportunity to gain insight into the lives of the Okinawan centenarians, but sadly only came away with little more than a few quotes about how much the elders love to garden and hang out with their friends.After reading this book, I thought I ask a real Japanese about ikigai, so I asked a native friend. I was told it is basically a lifelong hobby, passion, or profession. Sorry to burst anyone's bubble, but this is just another poorly researched and biased piece of literature romanticizing asian and "eastern" cultures and won't really provide you with constructive information.

title: Not actually about ikigai

text: Beginning with an overview of Viktor Frankl and logotherapy, I was all set to love this book. Unfortunately, it never provided the in-depth analysis I was hoping for. By skipping from Frankl, to flow states, to yoga, to the importance of diet, to qi gong and tai chi, it is a book that tries to do too much and ends up being something of a mess. The analysis of Japanese philosophy and culture is very short and superficial, which is perhaps the most disappointing aspect of the book given the title's promise. Checking in at just under 200 pages, however, this book is worth skimming through as there are some great tidbits on offer.

text: I like Japanese culture and heard this book positively reviewed on a popular radio show so thought iâ€™d give it a go. Spoiler alert, it basically says eat less, exercise a bit and have loads of friends. I already knew that and could have saved myself a bit of money. It also implies scientists are wrong about aging ( and implies the author thinks we are only a few decades away from being able to live for ever, despite some sad but pretty heavy weight scientific evidence to the contrary). It is written in a very patronising style as if the author thinks the reader is 5 years old and does the usual thing of preaching that the author knows best and that if their life style doesnâ€™t fit with yours then you are the one thatâ€™s wrong. Iâ€™ve never been a fan of â€œself helpâ€ books but after the rave reviews I thought iâ€™d give this one a go. I think I know who it helped, or rather whoâ€™s bank balance it helped, and itâ€™s not me. Put simply, if you have a bad lifestyle you are likely to have a shorter life than someone who exercises all the time, doesnâ€™t drink, doesnâ€™t really understand ( or want to understand ) how the universe works, gives their money away, doesnâ€™t care about possessions, and eats lots of vegetables. Or you can have a slightly shorter life but have a bit of fun. I suspect iâ€™ve left it a bit late for the former.

text: I found this to be one of the least captivating self-help books I have read to date. I was foolishly drawn in by the very nicely designed cover and assumed the content would follow suit, unfortunately this was not the case. This book is littered with constant repetition of very obvious and cliche advice. I struggled on through the boring anecdotes with the hope that it would live up to it's amazing reviews but I am still left wondering how this book has received such high praise.

title: Great book to get inspired and think differently

text: Talking about personal finances is often avoided despite its importance in our lives. Over the years, our have value systems have ingrained in our minds that thinking about money is equivalent to being greedy which is far from the truth. It is high time we overcome misconceptions and understand the importance of growing or at the very least (literally) maintaining the value of money we have as it is virtually impossible for anyone to work throughout their lives for money after a certain age.For those who are willing to take steps towards understanding the importance of money and personal finance, Rich Dad Poor Dad by Robert T. Kiyosaki is one of the books, I would recommend to start with. Written in a language that can be understood without any prior knowledge of finance, the book very systematically explains the importance of "financial Intelligence" and getting out of the "rat race" by making money work for us instead of the other way round. Although the concepts are based on the author's own life experiences which predominantly includes investments in the real estate sector, they are quite universal.Out of the many arguments put forth in the book which I mostly agree with, the most important one as per me is that 'financial education starts at home' as it shapes the mindset of an individual for lifetime. Luckily, mine started at an early age during dinner table talks with my dad.

text: ChatGPT Robert Kiyosaki's personal finance book "Rich Dad Poor Dad" was initially released in 1997. Millions of copies of the book have been sold all over the world and it has since become a classic in the personal finance area. I've reviewed the book after analysing it as a language model.As a memoir, the book is organised around Kiyosaki's experiences growing up with two fathers: his real father, whom he refers to as "poor dad," and the father of his best friend, whom he refers to as "rich dad." Kiyosaki discusses the financial lessons he picked up from both of his fathers and how they shaped his outlook through anecdotes and stories.

text: Rich Dad Poor Dad is a personal finance book written by Robert Kiyosaki. The book advocates for financial independence and wealth-building through investing, real estate investing, starting and owning businesses, as well as increasing one's financial intelligence to improve one's business and financial aptitude. The book is written in the form of a parable, with Kiyosaki telling the story of his two "dads" - his biological father, who was a highly educated but financially struggling school teacher, and his best friend's father, who was a self-made millionaire. The book offers practical advice on how to increase one's financial literacy and make smart investment decisions to build wealth.

title: Rich Dad Poor Dad

text: "Rich Dad, Poor Dad" by Robert T. Kiyosaki is a thought-provoking and eye-opening book that challenges conventional wisdom about wealth and financial success. Through the lens of his own upbringing, Kiyosaki shares the contrasting perspectives of his two fathersâ€”one rich and one poorâ€”and imparts invaluable lessons on how to build wealth and achieve financial independence.One of the book's greatest strengths is Kiyosaki's ability to simplify complex financial concepts, making them accessible to readers from all walks of life. He emphasizes the importance of financial literacy, urging individuals to develop a deep understanding of money, assets, liabilities, and cash flow. By breaking down these fundamental concepts, Kiyosaki empowers readers to rethink their approach to money management and take control of their financial future.The book's core message revolves around the power of financial education and the importance of adopting a mindset that embraces opportunities for wealth creation. Kiyosaki challenges the traditional notion of "go to school, get good grades, and find a secure job" by emphasizing the need to build assets and generate passive income. He advocates for thinking like an entrepreneur, exploring investments, and developing multiple streams of income.While "Rich Dad, Poor Dad" provides valuable insights and practical advice, it must be approached with a critical mindset. Some readers may find certain anecdotes and examples oversimplified or overly focused on real estate investing. Additionally, the book's emphasis on financial independence and wealth creation may not resonate with everyone, as individual circumstances and goals vary.Nonetheless, the book serves as an important catalyst for shifting one's mindset and challenging traditional beliefs about money. Kiyosaki's engaging writing style and personal anecdotes make for an enjoyable read, and his passion for financial education shines through every chapter.In conclusion, "Rich Dad, Poor Dad" is an empowering and influential book that encourages readers to think differently about money and take charge of their financial destiny. It serves as a valuable starting point for those seeking to develop their financial literacy and embark on a journey towards financial independence. However, readers should approach the book as a springboard for further exploration and adapt the principles to their unique circumstances and goals.

text: Rich Dad Poor Dad is an outstanding book that completely changed my perspective on money, wealth, and investing. The author, Robert Kiyosaki, brilliantly compares the financial mindset of his two dads, his biological father who was highly educated but struggled financially, and his best friend's father who was a self-made millionaire.One of the most powerful takeaways from this book is the concept of "financial education." Kiyosaki emphasizes the importance of learning about money and investing in order to achieve financial freedom. He writes, "The single most powerful asset we all have is our mind. If it is trained well, it can create enormous wealth in what seems to be an instant."Another key lesson from Rich Dad Poor Dad is the idea of "paying yourself first." Kiyosaki encourages readers to prioritize saving and investing, even if it means sacrificing some luxuries in the short term. He writes, "The poor and the middle class work for money. The rich have money work for them."Kiyosaki's writing style is engaging, straightforward, and easy to understand, making this book accessible to readers of all backgrounds and financial knowledge levels. I found myself highlighting and taking notes on nearly every page, as there is so much valuable information packed into this book.In short, Rich Dad Poor Dad is a life-changing book that I highly recommend to anyone seeking financial freedom and a better understanding of money and investing. If you're looking to transform your financial future and build lasting wealth, this book is a must-read!
date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on 28 April 2023
title: Life-Changing Book! A Must-Read for Anyone Seeking Financial Freedom, Wealth, and Prosperity!

text: Are you tired of living paycheck to paycheck, struggling to make ends meet? "Rich Dad Poor Dad" by Robert Kiyosaki is the personal finance book you need to read. This book challenges traditional ideas about wealth and financial success, telling the story of Kiyosaki's two fathers - one who was financially struggling, and one who was a wealthy entrepreneur.With ten chapters filled with practical advice and lessons, "Rich Dad Poor Dad" covers everything from understanding assets and liabilities to the importance of financial education and taking calculated risks. But what sets this book apart is its focus on mindset and attitude towards money. Kiyosaki encourages readers to challenge their preconceived notions about wealth and to adopt a more entrepreneurial approach to finances.But don't let the financial jargon intimidate you - this book is engaging and easy to read. Kiyosaki weaves personal anecdotes throughout the narrative, making the book relatable to readers of all ages and backgrounds. And with his passion for financial education shining through every page, you can't help but feel inspired to take control of your financial future.Of course, no book is perfect. Some readers may find that the advice is oversimplified or overly optimistic. But the book's overall message of empowerment and financial education is one that every reader can take to heart.In short, "Rich Dad Poor Dad" is an insightful and inspiring book that challenges readers to rethink their attitudes towards money and wealth. With its practical advice and emphasis on mindset, this book is a must-read for anyone looking to take control of their financial future.

title: Good book to get you inspired but could lead you to make some risky financial decisions

text: Rich Dad Poor Dad" by Robert Kiyosaki is a groundbreaking book that challenges traditional thinking about wealth and financial education. The book is based on Kiyosaki's personal experience growing up with two dads - his biological father, who was highly educated but struggled financially, and his best friend's father, who had no formal education but was incredibly wealthy.Throughout the book, Kiyosaki compares and contrasts the financial habits and philosophies of these two men, highlighting the differences between their mindsets and the impact that those mindsets had on their financial success.One of the most powerful ideas presented in "Rich Dad Poor Dad" is the importance of financial education. Kiyosaki argues that the traditional education system does not provide adequate training in financial literacy and that many people are held back by their lack of understanding of basic financial concepts.The book also emphasizes the importance of taking control of your finances and investing in assets that generate passive income. Kiyosaki encourages readers to think outside the box and consider alternative forms of income, such as rental properties or small businesses.Overall, "Rich Dad Poor Dad" is a highly insightful and thought-provoking book that challenges readers to think differently about wealth and financial success. While some of Kiyosaki's ideas may be controversial or difficult to implement, the book provides a valuable starting point for anyone looking to take control of their finances and build a more secure financial future.

text: I purchased and read the book "Rich Dad, Poor Dad" and I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed it! The author, Robert Kiyosaki, does an excellent job of breaking down complex financial concepts in a simple and easy-to-understand way.Not only is the book informative, but it's also a great read. Kiyosaki shares his personal story of growing up with two dads - one who was financially successful and the other who struggled financially. Through this personal anecdote, he highlights the differences in mindset and habits between the rich and the poor.The advice given in the book is practical and actionable. Kiyosaki stresses the importance of financial education, investing, and building assets. He also challenges traditional notions of work and encourages readers to think outside the box when it comes to generating income.Overall, I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking to improve their financial literacy and take control of their finances. It's an engaging and easy read that will leave you feeling empowered and motivated to take action towards your financial goals.

text: 3 stars book, 5 stars for the content and the message.I actually got this book back in 2003 or so, but discarded it.. big mistake!  If I had listened to him on RE investing back in 2003 and piled up, I would have done well, though it would have been a lot of risk as well.now years later, I decided to buy an updated copy and read again.  While there's not much new content, his messages are even more important today than ever.  As I type this, we're in global financial crisis, and a massive amount of wealth is completely wiped.  Govt keeps printing more money to save the stock market and economy.I disagree with him on investing in RE unless you got them cheap; in normal times, buying rental RE may be great idea, and I even seriously considered it last yr.  If I had bought rental RE, I be heavily screwed right now; we're heading towards massive unemployment due to the virus, so people will rent your apt units, but they have no money to pay rent and won't pay... they'll simply live for free, and you can't evict them either.  At same time, you're screwed with paying heavy mortgages.  RE investing is good if you're handy and willing to do most of the work yourself, but it's really a full time job if you got multiple units, and you must find good tenants.Going to college is not necessarily stupid, but going to an expensive one probably is.Owning a home is not stupid either, but owning an expensive home maybe esp if you can't afford it and do it just to show off to friends/family.I agree with those that criticize the book for giving no detail on how find and invest in RE or anything else; it does present a lot of ideas and makes you think.  And there's a lot of repeat in the book, just to be repeated again at the end of each chapter summary, otherwise this can be a 30pages book.if you can look past that, then it's a good book to read.

title: great insight

text: This book is written from the perspective of someone who's much older than those who are reading it.  The techniques he used to get ahead probably aren't going to work for the modern person.  The advice is all good, if you're already at least upper middle class, and need ideas on how to get ahead EVEN MORE, but they aren't anything groundbreaking.  The whole thing can be boiled down to make risky investments for a payoff later.  But again, this is 2020.  The author is 73 years old!  The reason he can keep doing these things successfully is because he has the money from a time prior to when money was heinously difficult to get for most of us.  Maybe in the 50's or 60's, you could get a job that paid you well, without needing a degree and the crippling college debt that comes with it, but that's just not a thing that exists in this day and age.  Freakin' fast food joints and chain restaurants are full of people with bachelor's degrees, trying to pay off $100,000 of student loan debt and still LIVE somehow.  The things that worked for his generation are NOT going to translate well into our global, internet world, where we are at such end stage capitalism that you're literally more likely to win the lottery than to be able to move up from the wealth class you were born into.  That's a depressing, statistical fact that I've been fighting to change my whole life.  This book gives false hope toward those ends.  It has no sense of reality, and its appeal is only in the sense of "preaching to the choir".  You want good advice?  Get a book written by someone who's made money in the world we actually live in!  This is just a boomer, reliving his glory days, pretending that his success has anything to do with his intelligence, when it was really just that he was riding that gravy train most Boomers benefited from.  Must've been nice to be able to get a good job, right out of your free public high school, buy a house, cars, and still have money left over TO invest.  That's not reality when housing costs are 300% or more what they were for his generation, even though inflation overall has only been around 20%, on top of basically being a second class citizen if you don't have a bachelor's degree.We tried free capitalism.  It doesn't work long term.  Time to admit that the whole thing is end stage and regulate our economy better than his generation did.  Don't take his advice and contribute even further to the stuff that made you want to buy this to get ahead in the first place.  Fight for better wealth distribution, for healthcare, for things that should be free to all of us when our country and planet are so abundant that we don't need this outdated system that inevitably creates wild inequalities.  I know you want a fast, easy answer to get ahead, but it doesn't exist.  This book won't make it happen.  If you have compassion in your heart for those who come after you, fight this garbage system we live in and stop supporting people who take so much more than they need, and give lessons to others about how to do it.  Gross.  People are going to look back on this period of time one day, and look at this whole thing, the way we look back on medieval kings and queens, who hoarded wealth while their subjects starved.  It's the EXACT same thing, in a different time, in different severity.  Just because we don't starve, doesn't mean anyone needs a billion dollars while the national median income is $61,000 a year, and the poverty rate is OVER TEN PERCENT.

title: Banger of a book.

text: Overall, It's a fun book, but it is full of not-so-good advice and just plain bad advice that you shouldn't take seriously. My rating is a reflection on the technical advice in the book, and if it's good or bad. I assume that's what people care about.Robert seems like the type of guy who would tell you not to go to school. Are you sure that's good advice? Would you rather have a degree or no degree when convincing people to invest in your business? Would you rather have a degree or no degree when applying for a position that multiple people want? While it's true that a college education isn't a guarantee of a good job, it still improves how people view you. It improves your credibility. So, if you have the chance to go to college, it would be a good idea to get a degree. Robert has also been quoted as saying, "the best way to get even with A-grade students was to make them employees of mine." Why would he say that? He most likely said it because he has something against people that are smarter than him. He seems jealous and bitter when it comes to education. He also wrote a book called "If You Want To Be Rich and Happy, Don't Go To School." Are you for real? I started out with nothing more than fast food experience and a minimum wage paycheck. I didn't get lucky like others who seem to just find success in work and careers. Should I have continued with only my fast food foundation? No, going to school was the right idea. Also, Robert isn't the best business man. He gets most of his money from these Rich Dad seminars and whatnot (which people claim are "scams." Research that for yourself), and has had various business ideas fail. He's not someone that you should go to for advice.So, why is this book so popular? Maybe it's because people enjoy this self-help motivational nonsense that just makes you feel good. I guess I feel motivated, but I'm really not going to be doing what he says.Also, the "Rich Dad" isn't even a real person. He made it up. And, who exactly has the luxury to be like the Rich Dad, someone who is able to create numerous successful businesses and have other people work for him/her? I don't have that luxury. That just shows how fictional the Rich Dad is. Most of us have to work for money (which is against his advice), because it's 100% necessary. I started with nothing just like everyone else, and I have to work. Most of his readers that take this seriously... I'm willing to bet they have to work, too! I didn't have a magic money bag show up that I could start multiple businesses with, and neither does anyone else. One 'serial entrepreneur' I know still has to keep her job, even though she has excellent ideas. This is often how it is in the real world! Robert seems to live in a fantasy world.His advice about homes not being assets... it's false. Homes are literally assets, considering that the definition of an asset is that it is property owned by a person or company. They go up and down in value, just like in the stock market. Simply citing the 2008 financial crisis isn't a good enough reason to say they aren't assets. You can make good and bad decisions with owning real estate, just like with any other asset. You can make money off of it, or lose money.In the end, it's kind of fun but it is generally a work of fiction. Though some things may be true (like his real dad being an educator), many of the things in the book should not be taken seriously and are fictional.

text: "Rich Dad Poor Dad" is NOT for the entrepreneur or investor who is already on their way to success. If you're hoping to scale up your skill-set, with tactical how-tos for your business, then this is not the book for you.THIS IS THE BOOK for those who don't believe that any of this is possible, don't believe that they "have what it takes" to be successful in  business, or simply don't know where to start. Rich Dad Poor Dad is the "red pill" that removes you from the Matrix; it opens your eyes to the world of financial possibility instead of the hamster wheel of 9 to 5 work that seems impossible to break.This is a mindset book for those that need it most, and frankly I'd say most of us do. If you think that going to college, getting a "good job", and saving 10% of your paycheck in a 401k for 40 years is the best/only way to grow wealth, then THIS IS THE BOOK FOR YOU.

text: Sir Robert nailed it!  I found this book pretty amusing book since the author, Sir Robert, was able to describe perfectly the characteristics of people who will NEVER be rich because of the incorrect mind set instilled by the old system (i.e. school, parents, etc).I have been an entrepreneur for quite a long time now but unfortunately, i lose money because I did not understand fully how the money works and the quadrant that Mr. Kiyosaki provided in this book helped me significantly in spending the money that I earn not just in my personal life but also in my business.Expect this book to provide a framework that can open our minds in order to fully understand what we are doing wrong that is why we remain poor.Expect this book to open the eyes of the reader to pinpoint what attitudes we possess and what we can do about it in order to escape the great rat race.Furthermore, do not expect this book to tell you where to invest your money, or what to do to become rich tomorrow or by next week.  Expect this book to teach the reader to change the mind set and the attitude towards money.Treat this book as a self improvement book, being rich is just the result of aligning a person's perspective and attitude.  If anyone wants to improve themselves, i highly recommend this book.  Learn the principles of it and put it into practice.

text: I am interested in investing lately and so many people say this is a good book to read. All I can say is... what does it have to do with investing? Everybody already knows the rich don't work for money and they make their money work for them. Not a new concept, and yes, I know this is old by todays standards. He has some interesting enough stories that may or may not be true about his 2 daddies but the lessons he learned (and is teaching) are kind of common sense/old hat and I thought everyone knew these things already. I even heard someone on a podcast the other day say they went back and re-read this, I had to think it would be for inspiration I guess, otherwise "why?". I can't see reading it again. I am looking more for hardcore investing knowledge, not some theatrical stories about someone's life and how they were able to swing a few sweet real-estate deals back in the 70s when houses on the shore in Hawaii were $18k (those were the days). I guess the take home on this would be look for ways outside of the common 40hr work week humdrum to make money, who doesn't want to do that?!?

Kiyosaki's point of view on how money works, how the rich view money vs poor, how the thinking of having more money will solve the problem, but it's the lack of financial education that is the problem amongst many others are priceless learnings.Without financial intelligence, we all too often use the standard formulas to get through life: Work hard, save, borrow, and pay excessive taxes. The concepts on taxes and cash flow pattern on why rich get richer and middle class are penalized are brilliant.If there is a book that's changed my thinking (and hopefully my life in the future), it's got to be this one. A book that will be my reference guide as I practice, take action and internalize the investor's mindset.

text: The timing of reading this book was perfect for me. Prior to reading it I read Overcoming Under Earning and Secrets of a Millionaire Mind. It has made me totally rethink the way I look at money and I expect more from my money. I wish I read this book when I was younger but better late than never. I am young enough to make a difference in my future.I gave it 4 stars for a couple of reasons. The silver bullet reference took his point way too far. Suicide is at an all time high and the reference is highly insensitive to people who have lost a loved one. Also I thought the review of each chapter was a total waste of paper.That aside, I feel like parents would do their kids a huge favor to make them read this book in high school. It's a good, easy read and I feel like I got a lot of great advice for someone starting out in life.

text: I heard about this book MANY years ago on a radio show and ever since, have had a craving to read it.  When I finally ordered it, I had planned to read it, then give it to my young adult children to read.  Now that I have read it, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  The method and mindset of this approach to acquiring wealth will probably only be successful about one out of a thousand tries.  In reality, I feel that far more people will lose what money they have rather than acquiring wealth if attempting the strategies presented in this book.I feel it is also presents a self-centered values structure and discredits many people (teachers, mentors, professionals, small-business owners) along the way.  To have a productive society, it takes lots of "poor dads" who are working hard and contributing in ways that have much more value than simply generating wealth for self.  I'll give it two stars though because at least I learned something from this book:  I don't want to be a rich dad.

title: Self Help

text: First regarding the POSITIVE:The author has one extremely strong, extremely true point (which explains the good reviews). Financial education in our education systems is non existent. Therefore people who don't have a teacher who is already rich (like "rich dad") it's hard for people to ever get there because they don't understand what they have to do.What they have to do is learn, aquire financial intelligence and invest like crazy. No fear, always on the lookout and strike when a chance presents itself. Don't buy liabilities like cars, homes etc if you don't have enough income from your assets like stocks, real estate etc to cover the costs. That's how let your money work for you to make more money.And that's about everything you get from the book.The NEGATIVE:Around this valuable and true message the author garnishes the story with standard capitalism statements, praising "investors" like Donald Trump all too often as his idols who - we all know by now - isn't all that good of an investor after all begging his followers for money...The book also is just way too repetitive. It explains a story/concept on 15 pages and follows up with a summary that is 10 pages. You basically read the same formulations and sentences again. How is that supposed to help or keep the attention? Most people start skipping through the repetition part I suppose.And that's the biggest problem. Whereas the author has a great, strong message he lacks in story telling and readers attention retention. A lot of the value gets lost because of it.For me overall a disappointing read that took me way longer than it should have - because of the constant and overhauling repetition and at points the lack of motivation to keep reading because of the reasons mentioned above.

text: I had originally purchased this book in 1997. I needed to replace my 10-year-old Jeep, with a brand new 2020 Jeep. I went to the bank and got an unsecured loan. Instead of purchasing the Jeep, I purchased a house instead that needed a lot of work. I renovated the house and got a mortgage for the same amount I purchased and renovated it for, and paid back the unsecured loan that was at a much higher interest rate. Then I turned around and rented the house. The rent payments cover my monthly jeep payments and the renter is purchasing the house next year which after expenses will pay off my loan on the jeep! I have used several techniques in this book which has very much worked for me! Before the book, the bank wanted to know what I had for collateral. Now when I go to a Bank they ask me how much can we loan you!

Ever since the U.S. government told landlords to not charge rent from their tenants during covid, that investment seems most unwise.  Becoming an entrepreneur may work for some but many businesses fail and not everyone has the cash or is young enough to start all over.  He may disparage his "poor dad" but maybe that man was way richer in the things that count in life than "rich dad" who was totally consumed by work.

I wish I had read it in high school, before I became a valedictorian, before I went to an Ivy League college, before I went to graduate school.  I could have saved a great deal of time, money, frustration and gained better focus.  I have spent the past 20 years unlearning what formal school has taught me, and this book can be your start to do so as well.

Each chapter ends with a summary of the chapter you just read, however these summaries often span multiple pages and end up feeling like chapters in their own right just repeating the previous chapter. There's a weird switch from first person in the main chapters to third person in the summaries which just felt a bit weird to me. But I would still recommend this for anyone looking to boost their financial education.

text: So I've given this a one star review and it's not because it's a badly written book, but rather because  the book seems plainly designed to lure you into parting with more of your money via his website and numerous follow up courses. The tale of his Rich Dad and Poor Dad is a nice one, though frankly it rings false, as does the man himself.On the positive side, the book does get you thinking about your finances, however it offers you no solutions as to how to actually make money. Like a lot of these types of 'self help' books, Kiyosaki takes one message and recycles it constantly. He is happy to tell you the problem, but not the solution. For this you should subscribe to his website and part with more money. This, undoubtedly, is where the real magic is and where you will learn all the great man's secrets for acquiring wealth. Enter credit card details here.Colour me sceptical, but I do have to wonder why someone with Kiyosaki's supposed riches needs to sell you these courses. Is it because this is truly where all his wealth comes from?If you want to make money, then save yourself Â£9.99, don't buy this book, and you'll be ahead already

title: Life Changing

text: Financial intelligence is not a bad thing to teach children, and the author's rags-to-riches tale is inspiring, but it's clearly just that, a tale. The character of Rich Dad seems to be invented out of the whole cloth and much of the financial advice in the book is baffling - it gives the impression that owning a home is a sucker play and that you can avoid ever paying tax by lifting and shifting collateral between investments indefinitely, ignoring the fact that you'll eventually need to liquidate and draw income and pay for accommodation (unless you live in your mum's spare room).There's also some advice in here which, at least to a layman, seems full-on illegal (the author at one point casually advises you to take part in insider trading, but "don't do it illegaly"!).I'd be very dubious about following any of the examples given here, even if the idea that you should think more about your finances is a good idea.

text: I talk to a lot of people about finances. 95% of them do not understand the importance of keeping costs down, automating investments, generating cash flow, etc. If they have $5000 in the bank they believe they can afford a $1500 vacation. This book is for them.For me, and I'm not a great investor, but I know what I am doing is prudent and what I could be doing would make me rich, I find this book frustrating. For example, the author speaks about real estate investing and has a line ending a paragraph that says "I typically only keep my real estate holdings for 7 years." and has no follow up explanation. Wait, why 7 years? Tax benefits? Depreciation? What's the strategy?I'll save you a few bucks and tell you everything in this book you need to know.1- Money makes money. Don't rely on a job. Invest in income generating assets.2- Don't buy a bunch of crap, consume less, save and invest more.3- If you do move forward with investing, incorporate your self for liability and tax purposes.4- Rely on yourself, it's the only thing you can control. Manage your fear of risk and be positive.

text: Outdated. Written by someone who did well because of property boom in the later part of 20th century. If you try applying same advice now, it will simply not work.There are some nuggets of truth here and there that will remain universally true, like spend money on assets instead of liabilities, but such assets now are oh so difficult to come by. There are many studies done that show that to be able to get meaningful stream of income from assets at the current returns, it is practically impossible to accumulate this many assets.
date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on 10 February 2020
title: Outdated

text: Robert will give you a financial reality check when you read this book, as the outlook he portrays here is required to achieve a modicum of financial freedom.Wastes a lot of time on his narrative and attempting to highlight his intelligence in the actions taken and the wisdom of his choices. Mostly you will be skipping quickly through the whole poor people diatribe to arrive to his point - which he never makes. Most of the ideas lack detail and here have no following actions or examples - just stories of being awesome and getting rich.Finally he forgets to mention the element of luck or the option of bootstrapping your wealth. Also seems very keen on tax avoidance and inside trading, which although they might not be illegal, it is a grayzone you do not want to tramp over. Doesn't mention anything on the number of times he filled bankruptcy.Don't buy into his seminars or other conceited material from his RichDad firm, its all a scheme. Learn the lessons, feel the pain when you comprehend the reality he displays and move on and to be a better person.

text: 1. Don't set Goals : Writer kehte he ki goal set karne ki bajay ek system pe focus karna chaiyeGoals set krna achi bat he lekin us goal ko achieve karne k liye system ko behtar banana padega jo hame us goal tak pahuchayega.Agar British Cycling team ki bat kare to gold medal jeetna to unka goal shuru re raha tha, lekin Dave ne jab system ko better banaya, to goal apne ap achieve ho gaya.Maan lijiye apka room bikhra pada he. Ap ek goal set krte ho ki mujhe room clean karna hee to ek bar room clean ho jayega, lekin agar ap apni chijo ko sahi jagah rkhne ki adat bana lo to apka kamra kabhi bikhra milegha hi nai.2 â€“ Change your Identity :Apni buri adato ko change krne ke liye hame adto ko chang karne s  pehle apne aap ko change karna ki jrurt hoti he .Hamari adte hamari identity ko follow krti he .Example k liye â€“Man lijiye ek insan cigarette chodne ki koshish krta he . Is douran jab use koi cigarette offer karta he to vo ye kahta he â€œ nahi yar, me cigg chodne ki kosis kar raha huâ€™Usnea bhi tak apni identity nahi badli. Vo apne ap ko abhi bhi smoker manta he.Lekin, agar  vo ye kahe ki â€œ nahi yar, me cigg nahi pitaâ€ is se vo apni identity change kar leta he. Ab vo apne ap ko non smokere consider karta he . This new identity motivates that person to stick with it.3 â€“ Change your Environment  -Hamare sath akshar esa hota h ki ham kitchen me jate to paani pine k liye, lekin hamari nazar chips k packet pe padti he or ham use khane lagte he .Hairani ki baat ye he ki hame na to bhookh lagi thi or na hi chips khane ki ichha hui thi.Malls vale yahi technique use krte he, mehange or profitable products racks me upar or ankho ki range me rakhi jate he jo customer ko easily notice ho jate he .And chances are that customers in products ko jrurt na hote hue bhi kharid lete he.Isi technique se ham bhi kisi bhi habit ko abopt kar skte he ya kisi bad habit ko chord bhi skte he.Fruits jyada khanee h ? to fruit basket ko vaha rkho jaha ap apna din ka sabs jyada time spnd krte ho. Jab fruits apki ankho k samne rahnge to ap automatically unhe consume krne lag jaoge.Padhai krt krte distract hote h to padhai k liy alag room, ya room me  alag table  ko study zone bana do. Yani padhai bed pe nhi usi enviorment m kroge, to apka mind kam distract hoga qki usko pata h k aap study zone m ho.4. Donâ€™t run for the best: Ek choti si interesting si story share krta hu. Florida University ke ek professor ne apne photography students ko 2 groups me divide kiya.  Pehle group ko yeh challenge diya ki unko pure semester jyada se jyada photos submit karne he , 100 photos submit krne vale ko A grade, 90 vale ko B.Or dusre group ko challenge diya to submit only 1 photo but that has to be the perfect one. Jiska photo sabse perfect hoga usko A grade, or us se kam vale ko B grade milega.Interesting.At the end of the semester saare best photos surprisingly first group se aye.Aap bhi soch rahe honge k esa kese hua, dusra group jisne pura semester ek photo ko perfect krne me lagaya unke photos best rank me q nahi aye ?Because jaha dusra group ek hi photo ko perfect banana me laga raha, pehle group ne jab bahot sare photos click kiye to isi ke sath unki skills bhi enhance hoti rahi. Vo har photo me experiment karte rahe or apni hi mistakes se sikhte rahe.Agar apko business krna he ya startup krna he or best idea ya best opportunity  k liye ruke he to ap kabhi start hi nahi kar paynege,Jo bhi idea he jesi bhi opportunity he uspe jab mehnat ki jayegi to vo hi best ban jayega.

text: Atomic Habits is a book written by James Clear that provides practical strategies for building good habits and breaking bad ones. The book is based on the idea that small, incremental changes can have a big impact on our lives over time.The term "atomic" refers to the small, fundamental units that make up larger systems. In the context of habits, atomic habits are the small actions that we take on a daily basis that accumulate over time to produce significant results. Clear argues that by focusing on making small, consistent improvements in our habits, we can achieve long-term success.The book is divided into four sections, each of which focuses on a different aspect of habit formation:The Fundamentals: Clear outlines the basic principles of habit formation and how habits work.The Four Laws of Behavior Change: Clear introduces four key principles for building good habits and breaking bad ones: make it obvious, make it attractive, make it easy, and make it satisfying.The Four Steps of Habit Formation: Clear provides a detailed guide for creating new habits, including how to choose the right cues and rewards.Advanced Tactics: Clear shares strategies for optimizing and maintaining habits over the long term.Overall, Atomic Habits is a practical and actionable guide for anyone looking to make positive changes in their life through habit formation.

text: A book filled with all the pragmatic approaches toward habit building.All in all, the author has done a great job as the book hits the right spot from the very start. It provides a reader with various perspectives, provides handy solutions, charts, and tables to enable the habit forming process. With the book, the author has genuinely tried on providing every possible tool for a reader to sail through smoothly in the process of habit formation and sticking to it.The book does its job of making a novice understand the way mind works, comprehending the science of habit formation, and providing the ways to alter the pattern by creating new habits or deleting the existing ones.It is packed with the knowledge of psychology, or on the actual wiring of mind. Also, it brings references from the paleolithic age from time to time, and the author has done an exemplary work at making it all interesting, and easy to comprehend via graphs, and effortless writing.Also, the author has mentioned numerous examples from day to day life, and from the sports team we follow from, from the last Olympics games and more, to make the subject or the topic more relatable.When writing is concerned, there is a consistency throughout however, there are times when it becomes repetitive and dull. Hence, I have rated it a 4 on 5.

text: I bought the book because it is a bestseller and had great reviews but when I was discussing it with my partner, I was asked a series of interesting questions.If there was ever an easy and proven way to change all bad old habits or add any new good habit, why the best-known minds in Psychology like Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung were addicted to smoking, along with best ever physicist Albert Einstein? And if someone has found an easy and proven way to build only good habits and break all bad habits recently then why it is not suggested by all doctors, psychologists and psychiatrists and why the inventor of such a critical thing has not given Nobel price in Physiology or Medicine as it would prevent so much premature death and suffering? How the claim of the author â€œguide for making good habits inevitable and bad habits impossibleâ€ can be possible when the human brain is so complicated, that still we understand only a little about it today? Also, can Albert Einstein or all other minds improve 1% every day for their whole life?I found all questions valid and the idea of the book deceptive. I soon came to know that habits are hardwired in the brain and to remove all old habits forever would mean physically removing all the corresponding neural circuits. What one can do however is to develop a new habit that can counter or control the old habit and it will take time and practice. But again, behaviors can be primed and automatically activated from the internal or external cues and it can get extremely convoluted because of endless other genetic, psychological, biological, neural, social, environmental, computational and rest of the known and unknown natural factors related to the human brain. It is wrong to say that we all can break all bad habits forever and add only good ones and it is even harder to decide what is good and what is bad.Identical twins are not exactly the same even when they have the same genes as it is the gene-environment interaction that shapes us and makes each of us unique. Many can obviously break some old bad habits and many can obviously build new good habits but not all can stop all bad habits and not all can install all good habits. And not all can decide what is good and bad. If that would be the case then the world will become perfect in an instant â€“ we all know what is good and bad and we all do it.Also if you are already at a peak, 1% improvement every day will compound to extreme new heights in a few years which is not practical for a brain that is bounded. If you are at the bottom, you can improve 1% every day for a few days but it is not sustainable. Information processing and storage of the nervous system is limited and it just cannot improve 1% every day, for the whole life. It is just not possible. No player always plays his or her best we generally tend to oscillate around the mean. If Einstein improved 1% every day he would have invented endless other new theories. At times we can improve a lot in a few days but not always and not every day.I was suggested book cognitive fitness by my partner earlier but it is was a little bit complicated for me and now I can understand why. The human brain itself is complicated.I am not sure about habits, but the author has sure found an easy way to make money.I may post more on this as I learn more about the behaviors.

text: In Atomic Habits, James argues that the most important thing we can do is focus on our habits because they determine most of our results.The book starts with an introduction to the author and his work as a habit coach. He then dives into the science of habit formation and lays out a framework for how to build good habits and break bad ones. The key highlights include:-The Four Laws of Behavior Change: cue, craving, response, reward-The Two-Minute Rule: start with something smallOverall, Atomic Habits is a highly practical book that offers readers concrete advice on how to change their habits. It would be especially helpful for anyone who wants to improve their productivity, health, or relationships.

text: I was aware of many concepts of this book through the web site of the author jamesclear.com  In fact that the place from where I came to know James first time.  The article on habits where he mentions process is important than goals was my starting point.  I continued reading his updates through the consistent newsletter he publishes through his site.Once the book was announced and available it was a no brainer for me to purchase my own copy to have all the concepts in one place and to go through the ideas in succession.This book provides supplementary material like cheat sheet and templates which are very useful for planning your own habit profile and continuous improvement.This book is action oriented.  The concepts present an action plan for trying them in your own situation and to practice the ideas directly in day to day life.  This makes the book an instruction manual for nurturing good habits and killing bad habits.  I was able to immediately relate to many new habits to start and many not so good habits I can stop and avoid using the identification pattern provided in the book.The principle presented in the book about understanding who to become, that is finding out what identity to achieve instead of just starting or stopping a habit is very helpful.One important aspect of this book is the to the point summary provided after every chapter.  Once you have read the book this summary helps recall all the concepts in short time and becomes a concise model to revise the concepts.The book is engaging and is suitable for reading cover to cover as it provides many stories and references.  As the concept of process than goals was already known to me through the Learning How to Learn MOOC at Coursera, I was glad to find the same concept mentioned in this book and was able to relate quickly with the principles.The book also becomes a workbook and reference material once you have gone through it.  The chapters are divided into sections which can be referred for particular situation in hand.I will recommend this book for anyone who is eager to understand why habits are formed and how to nurture good habits and avoid bad ones.

title: Atomic Habits by James Clear is highly recommended read

text: Must read
date: Reviewed in India ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ on 11 January 2023
title: Excellent book

text: Whether you are a victim of procrastination or struggling with your routine; whether you are a victim of bad habits or struggling to quit them; then Atomic Habits by James Clear, a consummate professional in behavioral psychology and habit formation, is the best self-help book for you. This book can make a huge difference that manifests remarkable results when practically applied to our life.It is divided into six parts- from fundamentals to advance tactics- which could provide a proven framework with examples, and step-by-step methods for making good habits obvious, attractive, easy, and satisfying and bad habits invisible, unattractive, hard, and unsatisfying. Every chapter has its summary for the readers to recall the important points in the chapter whenever they need.This book provides supplementary cheat sheets, templates, a journal that are very useful for the practical implementation of various ways and techniques mentioned in this book.I also discovered, at first to my consternation and then to my pleasure, that how basic factors, that are often underrated, are responsible for the formation of habits and making them long-lasting.The read is exceptionally interesting and flowing. I've completed this book within a week and, to my better understanding, I jotted down notes in my journal to implement them in my day-to-day life. After reading this book, I've been truly inspired by James Clear's work that I even subscribed to his Newsletter and 30 Days To Better Habits on JamesClear.com.I would highly recommend this exponentially self-improvement book to everyone.Life-changing Book5â­ï¸

text: I am not really a person interested in self-help books but this book has changed that notion of mine.The author gives real life examples before the start of each chapter which I found really interesting. For me, this book isn't just about habits or how to develop good habits and discard bad ones, but it is more about understanding 'why we behave the way we behave'. The author gives four laws of behaviour change and each law provides a set of rules to create good habits and break bad ones. The laws are explained in detail giving a lot of examples.Also, this book is filled with so many inspiring quotes! I love reading quotes when I feel low or demotivated and this book has so many good quotes. They are definitely going on the whiteboard in my study room!Some of my favorite ones are:When you fall in love with the process rather than the product, you donâ€™t have to wait to give yourself permission to be happy.Habits are the compound interest of self-improvement.The outside world only sees the most dramatic event rather than all that preceded it.Goals are about the results you want to achieve. Systems are about the processes that lead to those results.Energy is precious, and the brain is wired to conserve it whenever possible.It's crucial to show up when you donâ€™t feel like itâ€”even if you do less than you hope.The people with the best self-control are typically the ones who need to use it the least.Happy reading!

title: Must READ!!

text: This book would most suit the person who has tried time and again but failed to cultivate certain habits or the young hopeful, all the same.  It is not going to teach you to succeed in your goal. It'll point you to the right set of systems that might sustain your habit.The author, true to his surname, is very clear in the way he has progressed through the book. Each chapter is a beautiful extension of the previous one like how a water droplet follows another that makes a beautiful waterfall. Very well structured and thought through that it could well be a thriller.Another aspect of technique that i love about this book is the way each chapter opens. It's always with an example from a different field of profession - sports, operations, advertising, philosophy and so on. This makes you relate to the problem he's discussing in the chapter and the eventual solution. It gives a bigger canvas to grapple with the concept.Things that could have been better -- If you are someone very young and have not failed in anything before -  not everything in the book is for everyone. There are things that might work and some might not. The author also makes this disclaimer albeit a little late in the book.If you are searching for techniques to abstain from a bad habit then you'll be disappointed. This book doesn't have much on that front.  There are some pointers but not as detailed as the positive habit building techniques.

text: Just completed my First book for the year - Atomic Habits by James Clear..The Author has nicely explained the science behind the habit formation. He has explained how a cue triggers a Craving, which motivates a response , which provides a reward which satisfies the craving and ultimately becomes associated with the cue. Together these four, Cue, Craving, Response and Reward form a neurological feedback loop. The Author has used these 4 steps as a Frame work for building 4 Laws of behaviour Change. He has provided a simple set of rules for Creating Good Habits and breaking Bad oneâ€™s in this book and is a must read book.

title: Great Book

text: ATOMIC HABITSItâ€™s too early to tell if itâ€™s an effective book; but it sure is an inspiring one. Its appeal lies in making good habits seem so easily attainable. It highlights the power of tiny changes; of getting 1% better every day. Like, itâ€™s better to exercise for two minutes than to not exercise at all. Itâ€™s better to read just one page than to not read at all. Or for bad habits, try smoking one cigarette less even if you canâ€™t quit smoking altogether. It illustrates how a single and simple change can turn into a good habit; like by changing your environment to reduce friction towards the desired habit - place a bowl of fruits on your study table than storing it out of sight. Or signing up at a gym close to your place than one off route. It encourages locking your decisions before you give in to temptation. A lot of these tricks seem obvious and known; but entirely doable!The author, James Clear draws from the Japanese philosophy of Kaizen: micro changes, from Physics: the path of least resistance, from Biology: the response of our brains to instant gratification, etc. The drawback of the book, I felt, lies in that it lays a better roadmap for building good habits than for kicking bad ones.That said, after reading the book, I have begun going for a walk; remains to see how long I continue :)

text: There are some books which are feel good books, and there are books which practical books. Atomic habit is one such insanely practical book which can be applied in life the moment you started reading this book. I remember a similar book I read a few years back 'The Power of Habit' by Charles Duhigg. I would say this book is a easier version than the power of habit book. Concepts are moreover similar in both the books. This book is just written in way so that it's easy to apply the learnings from the book of n daily life. The four key things for forming habits cue, craving, response, reward are discussed in detail in separate chapters. If you are looking for a great book  on habit formation read this one first and then you can read 'The Power of Habit' book. Only thing I felt extra and not required is the last one or two chapters. The book could have been shorter. The reason I didn't rate it five star is because already another excellent book has been written on the similar topic by Charles Duhigg

text: James did a terrific job of knowledge synthesis in this book and Manson's approval of it as "a supremely practical and useful book" is not an overstatement.The author has ended my lifelong search of how to make habits stick, with his masterful display of four magic laws, and I am finding the book a nugget of wisdom.To me the book's premise (not necessarily the author's statement) is simple: If you want to get to your goal, change your systems, which are nothing but our habits. In other words your goals are defined by your tiny habits, and by corollary, your habits create your goals.By doing exercise daily you create a healthy you, but by smoking daily you create the goal of getting terminal illness. Habits are the foundation of the self.Mr. Clear, you've transformed me, down to the atomic scale, for good.

text: Great book clearly list out the problems which we face when we want to change our lives. It very distinctly mentions with detail the points because of which we fail and why we fail on them. The author has very accurately mentioned the various methods by which we can change ourselves and ultimately our lives. But after a couple of months reading it and trying out the techniques mentioned I find myself standing right where I started. After reading many other self help books from famous authors ,watching numerous videos on YouTube I am coming to a conclusion that it doesn't matter how many books have you read ,how many videos have you watched ,how many techniques you applied, until you know your WHY. Those who have already read different books on the subject would understand and those who have just started will understand when they are ready.Overall for the book I would say it's a great book which hits right on point. It's a must read for everyone who are trying to change. And it's a must read for those who have just started their journey on the subject.

text: Before starting this book, write down some good habits you want to build and some bad habits you want to break. This book is filled with practical steps and examples. Yes, there are plenty of habit-building books out there (just as there are plenty of diet books but yet there are still more new books published every year). Plenty of people are seeking the right book that resonates with them. The key points in this book are:* Compound Effect - Very small changes over time will have a big impact.* Habit Building Techniques - Make good habits into routines; use positive reinforcements and other techniques outlined in the book.* Monitor and Measure - Keep track of your progress and improvements.

text: Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones" by James Clear is a self-help book that focuses on the power of small habits in shaping our lives. The main message of the book is that success and achievement come from the accumulation of small, consistent actions over time, rather than one-time big efforts.Clear outlines a simple, step-by-step framework for building new habits and breaking old ones. He emphasizes the importance of making habits as small and easy to start as possible, so they become second nature over time. The book also covers the science of habit formation and how to design an environment that supports the habits you want to build.The book emphasizes that habits are the building blocks of a successful and fulfilling life, and offers practical strategies for using habits to improve health, relationships, finances, and more. In summary, "Atomic Habits" is a comprehensive guide to creating good habits, breaking bad ones, and living a more intentional life.But like all the self-help books it is not without the build ups. So getting the substance out of hay is a challenge.

text: Many people I know have read this book and recommended it to me since some time. While I read a good amount of non-fiction, I find new ideas are hard to come by over time. The good thing is that this book did have some well laid out concepts, and was also less pretentious than much of the self-help fare available.The central idea is that you can start small and build lasting habits. This book has practical tips for building personal habits. I liked the concept of â€˜identityâ€™ â€“ it felt fresh and very logical, though not immediately apparent. How we think of ourselves is critical to building habits. For instance, thinking of yourself as a writer, reader or runner causes the brain to react differently than saying â€˜I will write a bookâ€™, â€˜I will read a bookâ€™ or â€˜I will run 5 milesâ€™. Another important takeaway is around pursuing goals vs running systems. Everybody has goals and it is not goal setting which leads to success, but the process. There is also coverage on how you can approach habit building systematically and make it easy & rewarding.Overall, a useful book which I think should deliver results. The later sections are bloated though, filling pages â€“ when the content should have been far crisper.I listened to the audiobook narrated by the author, and it was very good.

text: Atomic Habits dwells on a premise: the smallest of a positive habit will create a profound, positive long-term effect.Let me confess by saying, that I do not usually read self-help or self-improvement books. But this book came highly recommended and as a gift to me.And it did not disappoint. In fact, it was a pleasure read for me.The book is simple and non-preachy.  James Clear has taken on a simple fundamental to create a winner book. Easy to follow and interspersed with examples, the book sets out to illuminate the power of cultivating a good habit to bring about a positive big difference in your life.He sets out to explain how to create good habits. Not an easy task, when you are trying a change which is not so easy (such as weight loss, boosting team morale, reading books). James Clear has presented a simple formula in neat steps for incorporating the change. Habit stacking, environmental cues, making the habit attractive are what he talks of when teaching us habit formulation.Actually,  the book has not thrown up anything novel. But it has very ingenuously used something very known and basic and created a story around it to emphasize the goodness and effectiveness of those ideas.What the book highlights and reinforces is:  Never give up on a small habit thinking that it will not bring about any change. In fact, the compound value of following the habit diligently and relentlessly is the secret behind the monumental positive change.As James Clear writes, â€œThe only way to become excellent is to be endlessly fascinated by doing the same thing over and over. You have to fall in love with boredom.â€

title: A small change. A big difference.

text: I had heard really great things about this book, so even going in - I had sky high expectations. And usually that's a terrible thing, because then no matter how good the book is, I can't help feeling slightly let down. Which is crazy, I know!But this was a surprisingly amazing exception. Because not only did it meet all the unrealistic expectations I had - it surpassed them!!It's definitely the best book on habits I've ever read!In-fact I personally found this one to be better than The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg, which I believe is more widely known as the go-to book on understanding habits.And okay to be totally fair - The Power of Habit did indeed help me understand how habits are formed, but it was also kind of long winded, and included organizational & societal habits too (things that I personally wasn't interested in).This one on the other hand, was a straightforward guide on habit forming and/or breaking with lots of direct actionable tips and advice geared specifically to the individual.Which is why if this subject even remotely interests you -  GET THE BOOK right away!

text: # Book review- Atomic Habits by James ClearWe all can agree that the easier it is to grasp a concept, the higher the prowess of the one imparting it. On the attribute as mentioned, Mr James Clear aces his writing and book. If you have not read any self help books and are willing to take a plunge, this can be a fantastic start.The phenomenal power of small steps compounded over time is presented tactfully in Atomic Habits. What this book brilliantly does is to effectively establish in the reader's mind that even a slight bit of effort towards realising a particular goal, say a habit, can have far-reaching consequences.Mr James uses real-life examples from sports, his personal life, readersâ€™ experience amongst others to drive home the concepts he espouses. This technique adds the charm to the writing.Mr. Clear outlines 4 laws to behaviour change and as mentioned, using examples and science, he makes it easy for the reader to understand and effectively apply it to his/her personal life. I already have begun to make use of some of the brilliant techniques and hacks I learned from this book.It is a must-read for anyone looking to improve their life.

text: The surprising power of Atomic Habits : Habits are double edge sword. Habits are like the atoms in our lives. Each one is fundamental unit of that and contribute to the overall improvement. If we get 1 % better each day for one year, weâ€™ll end up thirty seven times better by the time weâ€™re done. This make habits as the compound interest of self-improvement.  The see of every habit is a single tiny decision. But as that decision is repeated, a habit sprouts and grows stronger. Habits are not Goals. The goals are about results you want to achieve. Systems are about the processes that leads to those results. Goals are good for setting a direction, but systems are best for making progress. Habits shape the identity and a typical framework as mentioned will aid in building them.  They areCue : The cue triggers the brain to initiate a behavior | Craving : These are the motivational force behind every habit.|  Response: The response is actual habit that is performed which take the form of a thought or an action |Reward :  The reward serve two purpose â€“ They satisfy the trigger and they teach.  Reward teach us which action are worth remembering in the future. Behavior is the function of the person in that environment. B=f(P,E), therefore Motivation is overrated; Environment often matters most. Family and Friends in play a major role in  shaping our habits. Habit can be formed either using Goldilocks rule or two minutes rule.A good book to read.

text: Book ReviewTitle: Atomic HabitsAuthor: James ClearPages: 306Reading Difficulty: Easy to readGenre: Self-help bookRating: 5/5About The Book: The book is about how small daily changes can become the difference between who you are and who you want to become. Normally we humans overestimate the value of one big defining moment but it is all those small, tiny improvements that create all the difference.Main Theme: The main theme of this book is how to create good habits and break the bad ones in 4 simple steps (laws)Here are those laws;The 1st Law: Make It Obvious.The 2nd Law: Make It Attractive.The 3rd Law: Make It Easy.The 4th Law: Make It Satisfying.Best Quote from the book: â€œEvery action you take is a vote for the type of person you wish to become. No single instance will transform your beliefs, but as the votes build up, so does the evidence of your new identity.â€My Favorite Lesson: This book has many major learning lessons but I can't tell them all in the review ðŸ˜…As humans, we set goals to achieve the desired outcomes or results but when we fail, we think that we have set too high expectations for ourselves and we try to change the goals but it's not right, you are failing not because of your goals but because of the system that leads you to that outcomes.So whenever, you fail to get the desired outcome try to change the system through which you get the results.My Thoughts: This book is worth reading, every page and every lesson has Taught me something completely new, which I didn't know earlier. And yes, while reading this book reflect on the earlier times when you were trying to build good habits, you will certainly get a smile ðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š on your face and you will get where you were going wrong.Who Should Read This: Every single person, who wants to build good habits and those who have failed in the past from creating that habits and also for those who want to break their bad habits, In short, It's for every person who is trying to become the version of himself. ðŸ’ªðŸ’ªHave a Good One,Keep Reading âœŒâœŒ.

title: One of the best book of the year

text: Let me review myself first ! I've read hundreds of self help books during last two decades . Out of them , only 2 or 3 books were really good , practical , impressionable , and long term effective books . Most of them were just pep talks like believe in yourself , follow your heart , be mentally tough , God loves you , Manage your time well , get rid of your past , get rid of procrastination and list goes on . But nobody tells you how . But this book ATOMIC HABITS EXPLAINS YOU EVERY HOW , WHEN & WHY . James Clear (author ) seems to be a very honest  & learned man . He did thorough research before publishing this book . Every chapter , Every page , Every word of this book is PAR EXCELLENCE !!! Believe me ! This book will change your perapective about formation of Habits , and their long term effects on anyone's life outcome . This book not only teaches you to identity good habits but also gives you a detailed manual on(1) Build a system for getting 1% better every day.(2) Break your bad habits and stick to good ones.(3) Avoid the common mistakes most people make when changing habits.(4) Overcome a lack of motivation and willpower.(5) Develop a stronger identity and believe in yourself.(6) Make time for new habits (even when life gets crazy).(7) Design your environment to make success easier.(8) Make tiny, easy changes that deliver big results.(9) Get back on track when you get off course.(10) And most importantly, how to put these ideas into practice in real life.In conclusion , I STRONGLY RECOMMEND this book . You'll definitely thank me later . Best of Luck for your FUTURE IMPROVED VERSION !!

text: I depend a lot on my habits to be productive and efficient in my personal and professional routines. Habits have helped me get better slightly every day which becomes a lot better in a couple of months. I use habits for learning oil paintings, consistently working out, controlling my diet, gardening and being productive at my work.This started some time back some one year ago - when I overheard a friend telling how he learnt to play the guitar like a pro along with his tough office routine. He just said one thing - "I played for 15 min. every day without fail for the last four years.".I personally have never like Self-help books - and I was very reluctant when I started reading Atomic Habits. I was afraid that my own resolve and habits that are serving me well may get disrupted. It was a real shock when I realised that I had been unintentionally following many of the recommendations James Clear makes in this book. Most people already know that they should develop good habits - but very rarely they create a system to make these good habits their routine.This book helped me rationalise many of the benefits that I had been observing in myself. This book gave me a context and a story to further convince myself to seriously continue the good habits. It has only strengthened my resolve and has also provided me with more tricks to get better in my habits.The biggest learning was that the same process which I was using to gain new habits could also be used for eliminating bad habits - which I was not focusing on.I would recommend this book for everyone who aspires to be a better version of themselves. But I will also advise everyone who is looking to drop a bad habit - from smoking, eating junk food, social media addiction, wasting time on games etc. to pick up this book once.But more than the book - I will recommend everyone to first internalise that habits can make you better. Happy reading.
