text: James Clear tells the reader about the book Atomic Habits in the most effective and succinct way in the blurb: â€œAn easy and proven way to build good habits and break bad ones.â€He defines an atomic habit as a tiny change, a marginal gain, a 1 percent improvement. Atomic habits are part of a larger system. He says the phrase atomic habits means a regular practice or routine that is not only small and easy to do, but also the source of incredible power.Right at the bookâ€™s beginning Clear explains the fundamentals of atomic habits with a remarkable story of the British cycling team and their coach, Dave Brailsford.Until 2003, when Brailford was appointed as performance director, British cycling had endured mediocrity for nearly a hundred years. The difference was the new coachâ€™s relentless commitment to a strategy he referred to as â€œthe aggregation of marginal gains.â€ Simply put it meansâ€¦searching for a tiny margin of improvement in everything you do.Brailford and his coaches broke down everything that goes into riding a bike, and sought to improve them by one percent. Then, when everything is put together, a significant increase in performance is achieved. The coaching team diligently looked into different areas, including unexpected and overlooked ones and came up with one percent improvements. The results came quick and fast:The British cycling team dominated the track cycling events in the 2008 Olympic games, winning a staggering 60 percent of the gold medals. The team continued to dominate and set new records in the next Olympic games. In the next six years, British cyclists went on to win five Tour de France titles.The building of a habit proceeds through four stages, in the same order. The four-step process called the habit loop by Clear is not an occasional one but an endless feedback loop, active and running during every moment of oneâ€™s life:Cue- Craving- Response- Reward.The cue triggers oneâ€™s brain to initiate a behavior. Cravings are the motivational force behind every habit. Without craving a change, one has no reason to act. Response is the actual habit one performs, which can be a thought or action. Reward is the end goal of every habit. It satisfies oneâ€™s craving, while teaching which actions are worth remembering in the future.The author transforms the four steps into a practical framework that can be used to design good habits and eliminate bad ones. The framework is called the Four laws of behavior change: 1. Make it obvious (cue), 2. Make it attractive (craving), 3. Make it easy (response), and 4. Make it satisfying (reward).Enroute his exposition of the four laws of behavior change, Clear entertains the reader with inspiring stories, events and theories, seamlessly puts across the laws in the simplest and highly readable way. Here are some interesting revelations: Goals and systems:If you want better results, then forget about setting goals, focus on your system instead. Goals are about the results you want to achieve. Systems are about the processes that lead to those results.-The purpose of setting goals is to win the game. The purpose of building systems is to continue playing the game. True long-term thinking is goal-less thinking.-You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fail to the level of your systems.The Goldilocks rule: How to stay motivated in life and work:The rule states that humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are right on the edge of their current abilities. Not too hard. Not too easy. Just right.The core idea of the Goldilocks rule: Working on challenges of just manageable difficultyâ€”something on the perimeter of your abilityâ€”seems crucial for maintaining motivation.An excellent example of the Goldilocks rule in practice is the comedy career of American actor, Steve Martin. Each year, he expanded his comedy routine - but only by a minute or two. His victories were just enough to keep him motivated and mistakes, just enough to keep him working hard.Atomic Habits by James Clear, delves into the realm of habits, psychology, neuroscience, delineates steps, nuances and structure as to how to build a better habit as well as how to break a bad habit, build a system for getting 1 percent better every day, overcome lack of motivation and willpower and much more. Backed by copious research, notes, references and citations, Atomic Habits is indeed special, engaging and a go-to book.
date: Reviewed in India ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ on 21 May 2021
title: Atomic Habits is indeed special, engaging and a go-to book

text: Tiny Changes, Remarkable ResultsAtomic Habits by James ClearThe very title and the logline inserted with it provide enough glimmer on the theme of this book by James Clear. It is not only about forming good habits but also about eroding the bad ones. And the process allotted in this course of habit formation is superbly explained and illustrated by the writer not only in words and explanation, but also in multiple example and diagram.The book starts with an introduction, blood smitten and horrible. As a student of the sophomore year of high school the author met a horrible accident while playing baseball when a bat in a full swing struck his face and devastated it. Living with the post traumatic seizures and bulged eye ball from the socket, it took several months and years to survive, â€œâ€¦day faded into nightâ€¦ a series of machines kept me alive.â€ It was a real fight, and he took it as his challenge to come back to the life, â€œAnd I knew that if things were going to improve, I was the one responsible for making it happen.â€ And he â€œâ€¦discovered the surprising power of small habits for the first time.â€â€œâ€¦changes that seem small and unimportant at first will compound into remarkable results if youâ€™re willing to stick with them for years.â€ â€œWith the same habits, youâ€™ll end up with the same results. But with better habits, anything is possible.â€â€œHereâ€™s how the math works out: if you can get 1 percent better each day for one year, youâ€™ll end up thirty-seven times better by the time youâ€™re done. Conversely, if you get 1 percent worse each day for one year, youâ€™ll decline nearly down to zero. What starts as a small win or a minor setback accumulates into something much more. 1% BETTER EVERY DAY 1% worse every day for one year. 0.99365 = 00.03 1% better every day for one year. 1.01365 = 37.78.â€ Wow! How he explains everything in a mathematical way and pragmatically. We also get acquainted with many reputed theorists in the field of psychology and behavior like Thorndike, B. F Skinner, Charles Duhigg etc. and focus on the integrated model of cognitive and behavioral sciences and habit formation.â€œHabits are the compound interest of self-improvement. The same way that money multiplies through compound interest, the effects of your habits multiply as you repeat them.â€Every chapter, every line carries a message as strong as the fleeting arrow, just â€¦ from the bow. They fill the heart with strong conviction, deliberate motivation.  Good habit is the source of self control and only a self controlled person can enjoy the life avoiding the trapping of tangled â€¦he introduces us with the four steps of a habit formation - cue, craving, response and reward. Forget about goals and stay focused on system instead.Every line is spirited, and how my fingers etched on the keyboard to copy each and every line of it. The chapter summery again helps a lot to sum up and revise what5 we learn throughout the chapter. Itâ€™s a discrete choice of style on his pert and obviously a prudent one. He focuses on building a system and then a habit, â€œâ€¦do not build outcome based habits. But build identity â€“ based habits.â€ He also gives importance on the â€˜beliefâ€™, â€œâ€¦ if you cannot change your underlying beliefs you cannot change your habits.â€And â€œtrue behavior change is identity change.â€How he became a writer,â€ I did not start out as a writer. I became one through my habits.â€ He assures us that â€œprocess of habit formation begins with trial and error,â€ â€œwalk slowly but never backwardâ€ and the Goldilocks Rule.This is a book, not just to go through and stock in your book self, but a guide for everyday life, a friend in every adversity.

title: most inspiring

text: Atomic Habits by James Clear has been one of the beneficial books that I have read this year. And I wanted to share the notes and ideas which helped me with you all.The crux of the book is that Habits are the compound interest of self improvement.  The effects of your habits multiplies as you repeat them just like money.  A simple change in your daily habits can guide your life to a very different destination.According to James Clear,  all habits revolves around the below four step model and any behavior change revolves around these steps.CueCravingResponseRewardAggregation of Marginal gains:It doesnâ€™t matter how successful or unsuccessful you are right now. What really matter is whether your habits are putting you in the right path to success. Instead of focusing on your current results, you should you concerned with your current trajectory. Your aim should be to become 1% better everyday. Winning tiny battles like hitting the gym each week, reading books each day and spending less than you earn each month will define your future.Can 1 % improvement really make any difference?Habits often appears to make no difference until you cross a critical threshold and unlock a new level of performance. People make few small changes and when they fail to see immediate results, they quit. This is the prime reason why people struggle to build habits that lasts.Mastery require patience. Time magnifies the margin between success and failure. It will multiple whatever you feed it. Good Habits makes time your ally and Bad habits make time your enemy.Habits and Identity:The more pride you have in a particular aspects of your identity, the more motivated you will be to maintain the habits associated with it. James argues that identity is literally your â€œrepeated beingâ€. The frequency of your habits influence your identity and vice versa. The goal is NOT to read a book, the goal is to become a reader.Two step process:Decide the type of person you want to be.Prove it to your self with small wins.The First Law:Create a habit scorecard:Make a list of your daily habits.Once you list, look at each habits and ask yourself â€œIs this a good/bad or a neutral habit?.  Assign â€˜+â€™ if its a good habit, â€˜-â€˜ for bad habit and â€˜=â€™ for neutral habit.Design your environment:Environment is the invisible hand that shapes your behavior. If you want to make a behavior change, make a cue a big part of your environment. The most persistent behavior will usually have multiple cues.Habit Stacking:Best way to build a new habit is to identity a current habit you already do each day and then stack your new behavior on top.The Second Law:We need to make our habits attractive so learn to associate them with positive experience. Sometimes all you need is a slight mind-set shift.The Third Law:If you want to master a habit, the key is to start with repetition, not perfection. You just need to practice it often. The more you repeat an activity, the more structure of your brain changes to become efficient at it. Example: Learn a new language, play an instrument require repetition.Two minutes rule:When you start a new habit, it should take less than two minutes to do.Example: Read before bed each night becomes â€œRead one pageâ€. Run three miles becomes â€œtake out my running shoesâ€.The Fourth Law:What is rewarded is repeated. What is punished it avoided. Reward yourself after every new habit. Take a bubble bath or going on a leisurely walk.Never miss twiceYou donâ€™t realize how valuable it is to just show up on your bad days. Lost days hurt you more than successful days help you. So always show up.Create a Habit contract:Create a habit contract with you partner or your friend. This will help you stay the course.These are some of the best points I have found helpful from the book. Let me know if you have found other great tips for habit building.If you are looking for more Habit hacks, then I recommend that you follow James clear on twitter.

text: How long it would take to make a new habit? Many of us would've come across the famous answer "It would just take 21 days to cultivate a new habit." But James easily gets through that question in the early pages of this book by an evident "threshold".The author just spots the areas and hits the bull's eye in every single law to form or break a habit. The book is so tempting to know about the human psychology associated with behaviors. Each case study, each example, and each research associated with a particular law is helpful to create a lasting impression on the point that Clear is trying to make.While talking about Diderot with the "Habit Stacking" technique he slowly brings the current day behavioral economics. While talking about cues that are dependent on the environmental design, he backs it up with the Netherlands domestic power consumption results. While talking about habit tracking he gives a "moving-a-paper-clip-from-jar-to-jar" example. This way of putting things stays with me.Breaking down all the four laws and guiding on how to identify our niches based on trial and error methods that improve the favors of a game we would like to play is simply an eye-opener. I was so impressed with the detailed walkthrough of the "explore and exploit" method.If this book had just spoken about habit building, it would've been just another self-improvement book available. Instead, it just expanded the vision on why we need to build a retrospective approach behind the habits we wanted to cultivate at the end. It's equivalent to removing the tiny pebbles in our shoes before we climb the mountain.His simplicity throughout the book leaves me to grasp the point "never stop making improvements".We need to give this book to school and college students which would allow them to travel in the path of mastery.After all, Steve Jobs said,  "In the first 30 years of your life, you make your habits. For the last 30 years of your life, your habits make you."Recommend it? Must read!

text: Like everyone else, I want to get better. I feel if i am more consistent, my effectiveness will increase. Atomic Habits is a great book that helps you identify where the flaws lie. Not just that it tells you more about the need to make little long lasting changes. The author is objective and looking at his past, I am surprised he is as objective as he is. I mean with the help of examples and simple language, he makes you feel as though this book is the holy grail. Let me tell you about some things I loved about this book. The book says the following :-> Fall in love with the process rather than the product. This is important because when you have a goal, it can be so daunting that you will be unhappy all along the journey to it and only getting the goal will make you stop feeling miserable. Dont wait to give yourself permission to be happy.-> It is not about a single accomplishment but it is about a cycle of endless refinement and continuous improvement. Commit to process. The holy grail of havbit change is not a single 1% improvement but a whole bunch of them. It is a bunch of atomic habits stacking up, each one a fundamental unit of overall system.-> Good habits make time your ally. Bad habits make time your enemy.-> Your identity is literally your repeated beingness.-> acknowledge need of action by saying things aloud-> stressed at work? take three deep breaths and smile. Sad about life? Three deep breaths and smile.I loved how the author does not berate you with a bunch of things you are doing wrong. Instead the author makes most of the pages in the book in explaining to you that if you are not succeeding perhaps you need to make several small changes that add to the aggregate work of your life.I think it has enthused in me infectious energy. It has been 10 days since the book ended but I have been taking more action at work. I have been taking more pains with my diet. I now track my calories. I have been to the gym way more regular. I know I can't afford to ever miss a workout and if I do, then it can't be missed for another day. Even if I go to gym for just 10 minutes the second day.The flaw in the book is how much it tries to stuff into one book.The flaw in the book is that despite being of moderate intelligence, I can't remember all the things and have to refer to the notes.I feel as though the whole book is a waste if the reader does not retain everything.However it is nearly impossible to retain all things in the book without considerable re-visits.That is a good thing. That is a bad thing.Also the cue, craving, response and reward - four laws of behavioural change concept is a complete fail on me.So there you have it. I read this book on paperback but found reading on my kindle and phone more effective. But the print is solid and very good.Also there is plenty of times in the book that the author writes the points he discussed in the chapters. So if you were not paying enough attention, guess what? you get one more chance.Go read it now.

text: Many of you will find this book very simple and that's what the whole idea is about ,KEEP IT SIMPLE.In this book James talks about habits and that to very small habits which are not even worth noticing but will give you sudden results.When ever we want to start something new we always set a goal that seems to be un achievable ,for example if you want to loose weight you give your self a target of 5 kg or 10 kg and that seems to be very difficult so better start with half a kilo ,that might sound funny but with every half a kilo lost it will turn out to be 5 - 10 kg in few months and with every half a kilo lost you will feel a sense of pride and accomplishment in short run which you could not have experienced if your goal was 5 kg.Make it small make it easy make it attractive that's what the idea is about.One thing that I really liked the most is the concept of habit stacking . When ever you are starting something new don't plan a seperate time schedule for it but just stack it with your current habit.Example - When ever you are going to eat just do 2 pushups before that ,when ever you wake up in the morning just do 2 situps or meditate ,just before sleep read for 10 min etc.By applying this habit stacking I am able to exercise /meditate/read on a daily basis.It all started with 2 pushups to 20 ,from 2 situps to 40 ,from reading 10 min to hours of reading.--I was always lazy so I never exercise ,after reading this book I made it easy ,I fixed my exercise band to one leg of the bed so when ever I used to  go to sleep or I wake up in the morning or I pass by it- I exercise.--I was always eating like my moto was " eat till you sleep" so as the author says self control is very difficult for everyone to better make the things you want to avoid INVISIBLE ,so I gave away all the snacks and extra food stuff I had in my home and un installed food delivery apps and guess what it worked but yes you will still need some self control for not buying food stuff and installing food delivery apps.-- I was a social media addict always on my mobile so I made it DIFFICULT , uninstalled all the social media apps and before doing that temporarily disable my account.-- Had an habit of over spending and buying worth less stuff and just filling up the closest, so I pleaged not to spend a single penny untill and unless it's absolutely necessary and I started tracking my spendings on a daily basic.Smaller the target easier it is to achieve and more you do it ,it becomes a habit and habit transforms into big results. Just as every substance has a boiling point which is reached slowly and gradually after continuous heating ,so it needs to reach at a particular temperature before it boils,these small habbits are your continuous heating and sooner or later they will give you results ,Big Results.What changed for me after reading this book?1 I exercise daily and now I am in shape.2 I read on a daily basis.3 Binge eating almost stopped.4 More focused.Hope this helps..

title: Very insightful

text: This was a good book but it had way too much information for me to process. I went from feeling motivated and excited reading about the British cycling team to just wanting the book to be done towards the end.That being said I did find this book to be incredibly helpful.  As someone diagnosed with schizo-affective disorder ( a combo of schizophrenia and depression ) cleaning began to be so difficult for me. I tried to keep up but eventually I felt like I was losing the battle. My room made me so sad every time I walked into it. It didnâ€™t help that I moved from a bigger room with a bigger closet and more storage space for my stuff. I ended having things all over my bed with just a tiny spaced carved out for me to sleep. There were bags of clothes all over the floor. There were empty bottles or gallons of water everywhere. I just didn't have the motivation or mental energy to clean. I knew it would take at least a week to clean my room. Thanks to this book I realized like in the past just cleaning my room wasn't the problem it was my bad habits that was the problem.I would clean my room once every blue moon only to be met with the same problem. This time while it took a week to clean I have been able to keep my room clean by tidying up for about 5 to 10 minutes a day. This has removed such a stressor in my life. I would be close to tears walking into my room. Now I'm so proud to see a clean room.Also I picked up a habit of daily reading and walking. I still haven't been able to change my habits around cleaning the kitchen or the bathroom yet but I'm grateful for the progress.

title: Sounds Cliche But Well Explained

text: "Atomic Habits" by James Clear is a fantastic read that provides practical and actionable tips on how to make small but significant changes in your life. Clear emphasises the importance of focusing on the small habits and decisions that we make every day and how these can compound over time to produce life-changing results.The book presents a range of strategies for building good habits and breaking bad ones, such as the Two Minute Rule and Habit Stacking. Clear also draws from psychology and neuroscience to explain why these techniques work and how they can help us achieve our goals.While some readers may find the book repetitive, the message is clear: small habits lead to big results. I found the tips in the book handy and have already started implementing some of them into my daily routine. Overall, I would highly recommend "Atomic Habits" to anyone looking to make positive changes in their life. It's a solid 4-star read that is well worth investing time and effort.

date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on 3 March 2023
title: MUST READ if you want lasting results!!

text: Atomic Habits reviewâ€œGet 1% better every dayâ€.I am slightly biased in writing this review because prior to reading the book I already possessed a near religious belief in habits and how they impact our lives. Having read previous habit books like Charles Duhigg Power of Habits and Marshall Goldsmith â€œtriggersâ€, I felt I was at least relatively intermediate on my knowledge of the topic.Why did I read the book then? Because learning (or reinforcing learning) about habits is one of the most powerful ways for you to improve in the game of life. Your habits shape your destiny is one of my core beliefs so I am always happy to try to get a new â€œedgeâ€ or ways to improve them. I alsoexpected to find new gems that would help reinforce the message of why habits are so powerful and I was not disappointed.But enough of my own habits and life, the question is whether you should read this book? The resounding answer is YES.Honestly, who doesnâ€™t want to get better at something? Or who doesn't want to stop doing something?James Clear is a fantastic writer who I have followed his informative articles on a variety of topics for nearly a year. A lot of what is in the book is material he has written about on his website as other reviewers have stated but he puts it together in a very neat format for the book so even his regular readers should get something out of this. I actually took so many notes/highlights from the Kindle edition that I almost reached the publisher limit of 10% - a sign that I believe highly in what I am reading and want to reflect upon it for years to come.The opening pages of the book lay down a quote I will now repeat forever â€œif you can get 1% better each day for one year, youâ€™ll end up thirty- seven times better by the time youâ€™re done. Conversely, if you get 1% worse each day for one year, youâ€™ll decline nearly down to zero.â€ The beginning lays out why habits are so powerful and how habits shape who we are as people before getting into the HOW of starting to build better habits.The core of the book is based on the authorâ€™s â€œ4 Lawsâ€ of habit change - Make it obvious, Make it Attractive, Make it Easy, Make it Satisfyingâ€. By following the laws of habit creation we improve our chances of success in creating new habits.Without droning on too long, I must highly recommend this book. Even if you have no idea about what a habit is or if you are already advanced in the practising of habit change then this book will still teach you so much. If not just a refresher on the topic to keep you motivated. Seriously, anyone of any age could benefit from this book. It gives you the tools to start thinking more clearly about your life and improving it. I would recommend it to anyone over the other habit books I have read (see above) as it is relatively short and provides the â€œhow toâ€ parts on a silver platter.I will end my post on a few excellent quotes of the book towards the end (Ch.19 â€How to Stay Motivatedâ€ as this is the golden question for once you finish the book. A coach was asked by Clear what is the difference between the best athletes and everyone else? The coach said: â€˜the factors you might expect: genetics, luck, talent. But then he said something I wasnâ€™t expecting: â€œAt some point it comes down to who can handle the boredom of training every day, doing the same lifts over and over and over.â€â€œMastery requires practice. But the more you practice something, the more boring and routine it becomes. Once the beginner gains have been made and we learn what to expect, our interest starts to fade.It is a fantastic book but the key thing will be can you then translate that into action? The book gives you the best leg up you can get - itâ€™s then up to you to turn knowledge into action and go and get 1% better every darn day.

title: Atomic Habits is a life style changer in thinking and behavior!!

text: The "Atomic Habits" has become almost a constant presence in the best seller's books, both sides of the Atlantic - including an astonishing 150 weeks in the prestigious New York Times Best Seller List. Still recently published (in 2018) the book comes now with a small red note on the cover: "Over three million copies sold!" Is that all deserved? Is it such a good book?No, if you think of the many books published in the last four years that do deserve more copies sold or to stay in the NYT Best Seller List longer than this one - I could name a few far better books published only one or two months back. But reflections on the market and quality and best-selling charts and sales apart, this is a good book, well written, non-academical, simple, practical and that has managed to find a niche of readers in these hectic, social-media-crazy days and that has touched an obvious nerve. In this field, it's a good book that deserves praise - and to be read.One of its many merits, as I mentioned above, is that's very practical - it has good and ready examples of ways to improve efficiency and work; and in the way, to feel better. The author has also an obvious talent for expressing abstract notions with just a few words. His main theory, the "cue-craving-response-reward", while not life-changing is at the very least intriguing and looks easy to put in place and to be used as a blueprint for daily routines. The author tries and manages to get to his audience through simplicity - "I knew it, but I never knew how to describe it" is what the reader will say often throughout the text. In this sense is quite similar to another best seller of the self-help milieu: Dr Julie Smith's "Why has nobody told me this before", a far better, deeper book that manages also to reach and help its readers quite effortlessly, and that also has managed to sell in vast amounts. And, to complete the triad of current worthy self-help books, do try also "Can't Hurt Me", by David Goggings, rather different in tone, but very good too, and also funnier. (I've reviewed these two books in this platform).On the minus side, perhaps the text tries sometimes too hard in being too easy and becomes too basic, almost to the point of looking patronizing. For instance, with the advice on how to use less a mobile phone: by putting it in the next room. The book falls a few times for examples of this sort, too over-simplistic, as if it was addressing an audience of 7 to 12 years old.Also a flaw, and this one is directed to the publisher, it is obvious the effort in trying to present the book as much larger than it actually is. The book is crowded with charts, blank pages, short bullet points, sentences taking a whole page, etc. It has 270 pages and without all those wasted spaces it should have been 70 or 100 pages less, but then it would look "short", something the publisher obviously tried to avoid (it happens a lot nowadays), as if a book is better for being thicker or longer.So all and all, a good book that's far from life-changing, but in which everyone will find a few practical tips for everyday life; nothing more, but nothing less than that.

text: Iâ€™ve read several books on habits and this is by far the best. The author packs the book with lots of useful nuggets and methods around habit formation and change. His main thesis is that very small habits that help reinforce a strong identity will compound over time and lead to meaningful changes.The author suggests that most people see habits as the necessary means to some specific goal or event, after which the habit may cease to be meaningful. He calls these â€œoutcome-basedâ€ habits. However, instilling habits that resonate and fortify a personal identity, such as â€œathleteâ€ or â€œhealth nutâ€, etc. are much more likely to stick and accumulate. These habits he calls â€œidentity-basedâ€.He focuses on â€œsystemsâ€ over â€œhabitsâ€. Systems drive behavior and beliefs drive systems. He talks about how our language often reflects our beliefs and how making small changes in how we describe ourselves can have outsized effects on our identity and behavior. Ex: A recently former smoker is offered a cigarette and says â€œno thanks, Iâ€™m trying to quitâ€ reflects an identity that still sees themselves as a smoker as opposed to someone who may respond â€œNo thanks, Iâ€™m not a smokerâ€.The author introduces concepts such as â€œThe Plateau of Latent Potentialâ€ and â€œThe Valley of Disappointmentâ€ which describe the gap between expected short-term results and actual, delayed results. Early progress is often hard to measure and therefore often not obvious, when in fact changes are happening beneath the surface as your brain and body slowly rewire. This latent progress can demotivate us as our expectations often donâ€™t match what we see or feel.Like most other good books on habits, the author spends time explaining the â€˜habit loopâ€ process of Cue, Crave, Routine, and Reward. He emphasizes how architecting oneâ€™s environment to help reinforce positive cues is far more effective than relying on willpower and motivation. Our environment is the most powerful influencer of our habits.The author also presents several examples of the power of just showing up. He calls this the â€œTwo Minute Ruleâ€. At the beginning of habit formation, whatâ€™s most important is simply showing up. Many people wonâ€™t start a new habit because they view the habit as being large and daunting. But reducing the new behavior to just 2-minutes, and only 2-minutes, can help ease you into the routine. Other concepts include Habit Stacking, Habit Tracking, and Accountability Partners.Overall I found the book enlightening, engaging, and well written. If youâ€™re looking to engineer a better life through habit change, Atomic Habits is a great resource.

date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§ on 28 March 2023
title: One of my favourite most life changing books ever

text: I have subscribed to the author's email newsletters for years as I find them both motivating and helpful. His book is similar but is not a rehashed compilation of his emails-- he has actually done a decent amount of research. His biography is also very revealing, having overcome physical hurdles to achieve athletic goals as well as adopting a mindset in college that was different from his peers and allowed him to succeed in the classroom. Clear definitely has some mix of nature and nurture that makes him both intellectually curious and tenacious.To achieve a goal, focus on the habit(s) that help you achieve that goal instead of being fixated on the goal itself. Make performing those habits as easy and natural as possible."Whenever you want to change your behavior, you can simply ask yourself: How can I make it obvious? How can I make it attractive? How can I make it easy? How can I make it satisfying?""Instead of summoning a new dose of willpower whenever you want to do the right thing, your energy would be better spent optimizing your environment.This is the secret to self-control."One challenge I took away from this book is to get into the practice of "habit stacking," setting habits to be performed one after the other:"I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION].The habit stacking formula is: 'After [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].'"For example, I have a vague goal of doing more pull-ups. I hung a chin-up bar on a door that I walk past frequently. I have a rule: Every time I walk by the door I do one more pull-up than I did before. A good habit-stacking routine might be to think about one thing I'm thankful for after every pull-up routine. Or to also do one more push-up than I did before. Or, since I have a stack of thank you notes I need to write, I write a thank-you note after every pull-up set."Habits that reinforce your desired identity are usually good. Habits that conflict with your desired identity are usually bad.""Many of our daily habits are imitations of people we admire."Once I start doing pull-ups, I become a guy who exercises-- who does pull-ups. Pull-ups are a challenge for many people, so I can start to develop an identity that I do challenging things.The author also talks about the importance of making such habits pleasurable. Maybe I have a reward that if I do 15 pull-ups in a day, I'll let myself check Facebook. Seeing "likes" on Facebook posts gives me a rush of dopamine. The dopamine becomes the reward from my having done 15 pull-ups."It is the idea of pleasure that we chase. We seek the image of pleasure that we generate in our minds."This book helps you get where you want to be by helping you establish routines where you are today. Focus on the habit and eventually you'll find you've arrived at your goal.4.5 stars out of 5. As a caveat, I find these types of habit books more readily embraced by men than women. My observation is that men have an easier time being rote in their habits; eating the same meals every day (requiring the same preparation, same shopping list, same routine every time). This book had a rather un-emotional feel to it like many other books by men talking about habits and optimization (ie: Tim Ferriss).

title: MUST READ LIST

text: "Atomic Habits" by James Clear is a must-read for anyone looking to improve their life through small, consistent actions. Clear presents a compelling argument that success is the result of many small, seemingly insignificant actions, and that even the smallest change in behavior can lead to significant improvements over time.He provides practical strategies for developing habits, including how to create a system of habits that work together, how to overcome obstacles and setbacks, and how to stick to good habits even in the face of temptations.The book is well-written, insightful, and easy to understand, making it a valuable resource for anyone looking to make positive changes in their life. Whether you are looking to improve your health, relationships, or career, "Atomic Habits" provides a roadmap for achieving your goals through the power of small, consistent actions.

text: Some useful ideas and tips but some of the techniques would not appeal to all personality types. By definition, this book is about introducing incremental changes. As with a few other reviewers, I was miffed to find the last two chapters required me to give my email address away. If they were part of the book, they should have been included.

title: A clear message

text: I have just read this book.  I found it a very easy read; short chapters, large type face, 250 pages. Every chapter nicely reviewed, so I could go back and re-remember what I had read in previous chapters.This is the first self help book I have read, so I am not familiar with this genre.It is well structured, his main point being that is you structure your habits to be learnt and absorbed with your reward-pleasure in small incremental steps that are "obvious" , "attractive", "easy" and "satisfying" you will establish a new identity.  I guess it is pride in your new identity that makes it possible to stopping slipping back into bad old ways.  He also has suggestions for breaking bad habits, and identifying where you need to put in extra effort.I have always been a scatter brain, and have begun applying some of his ideas.  I think they are good ideas.

title: Amazing! This book really changed me

text: I've read a ton of non-fiction and business minded books and they all seem to have the secret to getting more out of your life, your business, your relationships, etc. That's all well and good, but the most effective changes - coincidentally - may in fact take the least amount of brainpower. They come in the form of habits, ways our brain have been wired to do things naturally and without thinking, and more importantly, small, daily or near-daily actions that trigger reward centers in our brain.Unfortunately, most of the habits we possess or continue to do are unhealthy or destructive. I.e. chewing nails, eating junk food, or just coming home and watching TV or mindlessly browsing YouTube or scrolling through Instagram. We do these things not because we're weak willed or lazy (most of the time), but because they're the easiest habits to fall into. They're specifically designed and tailored to affect the reward centers of our brain and deliver scheduled shots of dopamine, thus turning them into habits that are hard to kick.Atomic Habits, in a brilliant and knowledgeable way I think, breaks down the ways we can actually achieve more by doing less. And by less, I mean having to expend less effort in willpower, pain, or sacrifice than we're lead to believe. A perfect example in this book is this dancer (I'm forgetting her name) who's world renown and a master of her craft, and who doesn't have to remind herself to go to the gym every day. She instead views the act of going to the gym as walking out her door and hailing a cab to the gym. Once she's done that, everything else takes care of itself. So the habit is not working out, expending sweat, effort, and feeling tired or worn out, which is what many of us find challenging. All she has to do is hail that cab, and she's done, because once she's there she begins to work out. The difference is small, but releases this ability to get that daily workout in which is essential to her success.That's one example of many in this book that challenges one's thinking of how to be successful and create good habits. It's easy to believe it's all a matter of will, of getting motivated, of working off a spark of passion, etc. The truth it is has much more to do with routine, pleasure, familiarity, and route action. I highly recommend this book.

title: Devoured this book

text: We all have habits good and bad.  If we can shift out of bad habits, and into more good and healthier habits. We would improve our bodies, minds, economics, our families, communities, and our country.  The processes in this book, give a practical methodology to changing your habits, and making more rational decisions that are based on the identity / person we want to become.  If was can understand the Laws of Good Habit Building (Make it Obvious, Attractive, Easy, and Satisfying).  For breaking bad habits (Make it Obscure, Ugly, Difficult, and Painful), you can also combine the two to help motivate you in the right direction.  Wonderful, practical tactics for changing human behavior.  Second, it allows for greater understanding of the "Effects of accumulation results of marginal gains"  If you can improve 1% per week, in a year, you will have improved over 50% which means a fundamental change in who you are in most cases.  You have to set up systems to achieve your goals.  Prepare of unforeseen challenges that LIFE will throw at you.  Prepare three meals at one time, so you only have ONE major clean up instead of three.  Have mini meals ready so when you are hungry, you still stay on plan for your total caloric intake for the day.  It's NOT the goals, but the systems you setup for yourself that determine your success.  When you are about to make a poor food choice, you can ask yourself, "Would a health person eat this?"  If the answer is no, than you are re-enforcing your identity and goals of a healthy person you wish to become.

title: Fantastic

text: Over the past few years I have been an avid reader of James Clearâ€™s posts and emails. His blogs and other articles have provided me with a solid structure and framework on habit building thereby driving both achievement and fulfilment in everything I do in life. Whether it is healthy eating, hitting the gym, or keeping my focus in the work environment his advice, tools and approaches have greatly benefited me.I was fortunate enough to get a pre-release copy of Atomic Habits and jumped straight into it. It isnâ€™t a long read, however, it is structured in a way that provides a good overview of why habits are important, tools and techniques on how to establish habits as well as a plethora of real life examples. James also makes reference to an additional set of tools on the Atomic Habits website which you can also leverage (e.g. habit trackers, cheat sheets, guides etc.)The book centres on the both on the four stages of developing a habit and the laws of behaviour change. The latter he delves into in great detail, again with many examples on how to apply within your own life given constraints. The book had a nice pace and balance on theory and application.The biggest thing I have learned (also from his blogs) is the difference between goals and habits. For example, instead of setting a goal, create an identity and establish small habits that align to that identity. For example, donâ€™t say you want to lose weight, but rather identify with being a healthy person that exercises most days and eats well. The habits might be drinking x amount of water a day, 10 push-ups a day, walking 10,000 steps per day etc; and increase the habits once they are firmly established.Given the applicability of this topic, it is a book everyone should read. Unfortunately there are many key areas we donâ€™t get educated on at school. This is one area that is important for life in everything that we do. Highly recommend Atomic Habits!Three key takeaways from the book:1. Habit stacking. Put your clothes out next to your bed before going to sleep so that when you wake up it is the first thing you do or think about. That habit will then drive the habit to go to the gym etc.2. Look to establish identity habits versus reaching for goals or developing finite habits. Habits based on beliefs are much more powerful.3. When it comes to wanting to do something (good or bad) 90% of the dopamine release is driven by the desire versus and 10% on the actual experience.

title: Life changing

text: On reflection, I am not sure that I added a great deal to my stock of knowledge about human habits from reading this book. But I did find the presentation of the material here very clear and very persuasive - and it might actually lead to changes in my life  - where previous reading about habits has simply added to my stock of knowledge.Particularly interesting, and particularly easy to implement are the thoughts that: it's helpful to take stock of habits and think what you want to do about them (after all you've acquired them rather randomly through life), and that it's fairly easy to do something about them - form intentions that are linked to 'cues' or times and places (rather than just vague intentions) and reflect on what it's very easy to do to get a habit going - read one page of a book at bedtime for example, not a chapter, and find habits that themselves bring rewards (find a nice flavour of toothpaste for example)...and it's also good on bad habits (mostly: avoid cues, like returning Vietnam vets avoided Vietnam cues - or you might keep alcohol or high sugar drinks out of the house)...There's a bit of helpful overall encouragement too - small changes to habits can add up to big changes in your life...And some further material that while interesting (for example a comparison of the physiques of swimmers and middle distance runners) seems a little set apart from the main themes of the book...Sometimes you might question the analysis (is over-eating really because we are suckers for high fat high sugar foods due to our genes, or is it that 'we need protein and will eat till we get it' as for example in the book Eat Like The Animals - which is an interesting variant on this theme)....Overall, though, strongly recommended.

text: Although a large percentage of the 2300 plus books I have read since January 2000 are audio, mostly from Audible, I feel this is a case where you need a print edition.  With non-fiction books I like to mark the margin in pencil to identify key points, then create my own index, and that is certainly the case here.  Although James provides a chapter summary, which is most useful, the items that have relevance for you are worth noting.  James kindly sent me chapter 1, as he no doubt did to tens of thousands on his mailing list.  I found this most interesting and prompted me to buy two copies (one to loan to friends) in due course.  On reflection it occurred to me that there are 1440 minutes in the day, 1% being 14.4 minutes.  Round that up to 15 minutes â€“ a quarter of an hour.  All of us can devote 1% a day to a desired project, and over time that adds up.  I decided that apart from whatever else I was doing in the writing field, preparing my novel THE PRICE TO PAY and a collection of 25 short stories â€“ THE FORK IN THE ROAD â€“ to go on Kindle, etc. I would devote 1% a day to writing a new short story.  Consequently, since the end of October 2018 I have written 8 stories with a word count of a bit over 38,000 words.  I do acknowledge that when the creative process is upon me and I am nearing the end I might get up at 4:30 am and write for a couple of hours, but it has been an excellent discipline.  I believe that anyone who wants to improve their productivity, refine the process by which they achieve this and become more efficient in achieving your goals, ATOMIC HABITS is a book to read, then read again and again.  Thank you James for your excellent â€˜Giving Attitudeâ€™ â€“ you deserve all your success and are entitled to enjoy both the tangible and the intangible moments as you pass the markers along Success Road.Eric J Drysdale â€“ em:  ericjdrysdale@gmail.com

text: 8/10Atomic Habits is a useful book. Itâ€™s a practical guide to identifying and changing your habits. Itâ€™s something you can actually put into practice in your life.I think that all of the concepts in the book are good and useful to know but some of the action points I think are slightly oversimplified. If you take the action points in some chapters and modify them to your specific situation you can still apply most of them but you do have to do some critical thinking with the material.I like that the book is simple and straightforward. James Clear doesnâ€™t bog you down with a lot of conceptual material. He starts each chapter with an example (some are better than others), gives you the concept plainly, and then gives you concrete actions to apply the concept in real life. Itâ€™s a nice formula. Each chapter is roughly 15-20min.This book is worth reading. Itâ€™s easy to apply the knowledge and action steps. Even if it doesnâ€™t completely change your behavior, it will make you more aware of yourself. It provides a good lens that you can use to view yourself and others. I would recommend it to anyone who is trying to really set an air-tight routine. If you follow the book you can definitely make something a habit.Iâ€™m a fan of James Clear. I have read his newsletter for about 2yrs now. His newsletter is one of the best Iâ€™ve read because itâ€™s interesting and well researched and always has some take away for me. His book is really an expansion on a lot of things heâ€™s covered in his newsletter. There are some chapters that I was already very familiar with because I had read his previous material on it. This doesnâ€™t detract from the book. He expands on most things heâ€™s written about before. The book is laid out like a road map and builds upon itself, which is something you donâ€™t really get from the newsletter.The intro is pretty graphic. Itâ€™s about a personal injury the author has faced. I recommend being prepared for that. Once you get through that itâ€™s all good.

text: Firstly, i do not agree with some of the reviews this book has received. As someone who hates the American self help "you can do it" crap, i do not agree that this book is one of those. This book i is a very clearly written tool for creating new good habits and destroying old bad habits. There is no "find yourself, be one with the habit" rubbish that people seem to be talking about; there are lots of scientific and academic references to back up what he is saying. Each step of creating a new habit (or destroying an old one) is broken down and an example from business or sport is given to add  emphasis to why this is relevant, a credible example.I have not thought about my bad habits in the way presented in this book and i will definitely be using its tools too remove my old habits and create new ones. An excellent read.

title: An eye opener

text: Though well-written, this book seems to be more of a rather premature autobiography of a 20-something year old wealthy white male.Granted, he has overcome some first-world adversity, but I found the underlying message to be repetitive and better suited to teenagers or young adults who lack drive and direction.The underlying message, over and over (and over) is to persist with positive behaviours and they will eventually become a habit.It is well-studied that if you repeat an action 27 days in a row, it becomes a habit. That is the general crux of this book and I thought this was something most people already knew.It also appeared to me that the author has lived quite a privileged life and doesn't seem to yet understand what lifelong adversity is via lower to middle-class cards most of us are dealt in life, so if you are 30+ and have suffered many setbacks in life because you didn't win the 'family lottery', you will likely find this book mildly irritating.I personally found this book useless as I do not lack drive or ambition at all and unfortunately can't relate to a wealthy high-school jock who hurt himself playing a notoriously dangerous sport.I'll probably keep it for when my son starts reading novels.

This is extraordinary, and out of curiosity I decided to try it.James Clear is not a scientist, though heâ€™s a self-declared expert on habits, and my first impression of the book as I read about a childhood accident he had, his experience as a baseball player and businessman, was not a good one. But the book grew on me.He writes well, he cites good sources (all footnoted), he sums up his main points at the end of every (very short) chapter, and the book makes sense.The basic point â€“ made by him and others who write about this field â€“ seems to be to make small changes, be consistent, and over time youâ€™ll get results.If youâ€™re struggling with the examples he frequently cites â€” you want to lose weight, read more books, do better in your profession, etc. â€” this book is not a bad place to start.

title: One Steps at a time

text: I honestly didn't have many expectations when I bought this book to find out what the fuss was about --- all these high ratings and strong reviews. I can say I've been pleasantly surprised.I'll be revisiting and rereading the book from time to time because there's so much in there to absorb and implement. Some may find it overwhelming, particularly if they're feeling they need to instil many habits with a limited amount of time, as the book is detailed and isn't about quick fixes. A delve into the fascinating psychological underpinnings of our habits combined with an actionable guide implementing habits you would like to do more of and lessening the habits you would like to stay away from. It isn't a one size fits all solution, so taking the time to understand why things that are working work well, and the things that don't stick with us is important. The author has really put in the effort to share his expertise on habits in a way that is digestible and informative. Given the complexity of human beings, it's no wonder it takes a whole book just to get into habit formation. The book stays illuminating til the end.Well worth the purchase, will be a staple in my library whose many wise ideas I'll be sharing with others. Please take the time to read it with an open mind, hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

title: I can see why...

text: Like many of his contemporaries, James Clear is here re-framing ideas that have always been with us, a combination of ancient philosophy and modern science.  Commonly called 'self-help', another collective term of these works may be the genre of 'Intentionality.'  Intentional living, being purposeful, and having a system to embed that purpose, to achieve a dynamic momentum that will propel you forward.Here the system is about noticing the triggers in our lives for good and bad behaviours, and being intentional about them.  Building on them.  So you build motivators onto and generate the triggers that are good for you and improve you.  You make the bad triggers as intentionally as unpleasant as possible.  The titular 'Atomic Habits' are the small things that on their own are negligible, but cumulatively, to borrow a key phrase from this book, they stack up, and tip the scales, one way or another.  James Clear here gives us a system to help us tip the scales in our favour.Like many of this genre chapters are introduced with various hard won paths to success of those who have excelled at their craft, be that sports, business, science, arts.  We then dig into the moral of their story and a new feature of the habits system is explored.  Each chapter ends with a bullet point summing up.The book's soul is with behavioural science.  It is a very 'bio-mechanical' view of life and endeavour that lacks mystery and real profundity.  It's all rather clinical.Still, it's like watching a Ted talk where the person's breathless delivery at least makes you listen.  And we can all do with a bit of extra intentionality.

text: Clear provides the reader with some practical ways to build and maintain habits. I especially like that he provides four clear ways to build and maintain good habits, while offering four ways to break bad habits we all tend to build over time. A few other takeaways for me. First, the importance of habit stacking. Clear suggests building habits in a way that one action triggers another. Bedtime routines are an example of this. I have implemented this in my own routine and it has been helpful. The chapter that discussed building in accountability for your habits was also helpful. Though the example he provided was extreme (a guy entered a pretty stringent â€œcontractâ€ with his wife and trainer), I can see how accountability can help with habits. Overall, a good read on creating and sustaining habits.

text: I was a bit skeptical when I ordered it as I suspected either: 1) a repetitive farrago of cheesy platitudes, or: 2) â€˜inspiringâ€™ success stories of people naturally endowed with tremendous willpower, steely resolve, and steadfast belief in oneâ€™s own worth. On the contrary, this approach is at the same time practical, grounded in science, and eminently â€˜humanâ€™. With â€˜humanâ€™ I mean based on a solid, deeply emphatic understanding of the way ordinary people think, act, and make mistakes, not on ideal, out-of-reach models.Hereâ€™s the nub of it: change doesnâ€™t necessary start with a powerful resolution or a clean cut, it may well be the incremental effect of minuscule (hence the title) adjustments in the way we go about with our daily lives. Improvement is the outcome of a gradual and methodical process of removing what doesnâ€™t work and replacing it with more effective habits. Small, sustained changes can have big future impacts.Mind you. Thereâ€™s nothing 100% original in the book, but the way the material is presented is good: eminently readable; practical, and nicely organised in short chapters. Some methods are surprisingly clever, can be implemented in no time, and look effective. Highly recommended.

text: Man! this guy did a great job here. As he explains it in the book, it was all about the system I was using. Whenever I started something new, I was trying to kill it from the beginning, and I just got myself worn out quickly. Everything I mentioned above, I started doing it for no more than 5 minutes a day, and then I just add it a minute every month. By itself, a minute is not much, but after a few months, I started to feel the difference. I used to wonder what was wrong with me! I wanted to start and finish things, especially studying languages, since I love speaking different languages. I got excited for the first few days, and then quit. Not anymore! I even work out every day and I enjoy it and look forward to it! A little at a time. Compound Interest baby!

text: I chanced upon James Clearsâ€™ blog on a random Google search for my â€œNext Book to Readâ€. After checking his list of recommendations, I read a few of his posts and I was hooked. The writing was easy to read and understand, his research thorough and reading his posts felt like having a personal life coach cheering you from afar.When I saw Atomic Habits listed on his website, I was very keen to read it. Fast forward 6 months, I finally purchased the kindle version and I am thrilled with it. The book follows his usual style of writing â€“ which is crisp, easy to read and packs a punch. There are actionable insights in the book, that when implemented consistently, can bring about significant changes in our lives. No task seems too big to achieve â€“ ask anyone who has tried building a new habit or deleting an old one from their lives, how difficult it is to keep at it for 21 days or 60 or 90 (depending on which literature youâ€™re reading). But the methods listed in this book can allow you to overcome failure just as easily as they encourage you to successfully implement new habits.The ideas listed in the book are forgiving and generous, quite literally, where some ask you to focus on incremental gains, some donâ€™t reprimand you for missing one day of a new diet / workout schedule, others give you simple, straightforward suggestions to increase your chances of success in implementing new habits.Thereâ€™s no long story, scientific jargon, unnecessary fillers or flimsy writing to make you NOT want to turn the page. This is definitely worth your money and time.

text: Updated review: decent but seriously overhyped, this book is a watered-down, distorted shadow of Tiny Habits by BJ Fogg.  If this book is from the Stone Age, then Tiny Habits is from the Space Age.  Neither book is complete, because the important roles of motivation and neurophysiology are not discussed sufficiently at all.  There are critically important, yet subtle points about the behavior change process that Clear misses in Atomic Habits but that Fogg emphasizes in Tiny Habits.  Tiny Habits is far more elegant, more concise, and presents a self-contained system that's effective and universal and also explains anything in Clear's book more neatly than Clear presents it himself.  If you have to choose between this book and Tiny Habits, I strongly recommend reading and using Tiny Habits instead.  Even if you've read this book, you should read Tiny Habits to pick up what you've missed out on here and to really calibrate your behavior-change system.  Atomic Habits smacks of being written by a motivational writer with a strong interest in habits who decided to cash in on his large email list with a book deal, while Tiny Habits is written by an actual behavior researcher and educator who actually trained tens of thousands of people in his technique before deciding to write a book.  The only way in which Atomic Habits is superior to Tiny Habits is in its discussion of meta-habits (see the section on annual and semiannual reviews).  But even that stuff is freely available online in podcasts and blogs.  I couldn't pick out a single original idea in this book.

text: This book just might be the most important book you ever read.We all know what we need to do to be successful but we don't do it. Why? We have the wrong habits. We surf the net when we know we should be starting the company we know we can. We eat candy when we know we should be eating something healthily... and so on. By why do we do these things we know are wrong? And why don't we do the things we know are right? Because we have the wrong habits. I used to think that will power was something you either had innately or you didn't. The author clearly explains that this is not true. Will power is more about your environment than anything innate. He also explains how to change your environment to get rid of bad habits and instil new, good ones. I read this book a week ago and it has already changed my life. Read it, summarise it and re-read the summary. Treat it like a book you have to master for university exams. It's brilliant and if you apply the rules, you have every chance of realising your potential.

text: Â I am a business owner from Berlin, Germany. I profited a lot from this book. In this short review, I'd like to highlight just three concepts from the book.First, the author says that habits are the compound interest of self improvement. Many people give up a long time before they can experience the compound effect of their efforts. So when going after a worthwile goal, then what is needed is a lot of patience and perseverence.Second, the author says it's good to have goals but it's so much better to have a system and concentrate on executing the system instead. Because if we do just that, we can be happy every time we execute our plan.Third, identity change is the fastest way to get what we want in life.Instead of saying: "I want to work out three times a week" we could be saying: "I am an athletic person" or instead of saying "I want to write a book" we should be saying to ourselves: "I am an author" - because what does an author do? He writes. It's really as easy as that.

text: This is a great book. I have found it the best and most useful book on Habits I have read so far. One of the aha helpful things was the idea that you must first establish your identity, and then the habit (behaviour) reinforces that. Rather than tying to do it the other way around. Viz (quoting from the book): "Doing the right thing is easy. After all, when your behavior and your identity are fully aligned, you are no longer pursuing behavior change, you are simply acting like the type of person you already believe yourself to be."  And "It is a simple two-step process: Decide the type of person you want to be. Prove it to yourself with small wins." and finally to reinforce this point "The most effective way to change your habits is to focus not on what you want to achieve, but on who you wish to become".Also, the author has developed a clear framework called 'The Four Laws of Behavior Change" which provides a simple set of rules (laws) for creating good habits and breaking bad habits. And you are taken step by step through each law, given plenty of practical examples, and there is a summary at the end of each chapter which reinforces the main learning points.Thanks for writing this book Mr James Clear! It has helped me tremendously!

text: This is not a book to read once for fun and then stick it on the shelf.Donâ€™t get me wrong, itâ€™s a terrific read with fascinating stories, examples, and research. (The authorâ€™s personal story, which involves a horrifying incident with a baseball bat, gets you turning pages fast.)But the real value is in what you can do with what you learn.Iâ€™ve been reading James Clear's blog for a while and was fortunate to get advance access to the book. Iâ€™ve gone through it three times already. Took copious notes. Started implementing the techniques. And itâ€™s powerful stuff.Donâ€™t be fooled by the topic â€” â€œhabitsâ€ sounds a bit dreary.But the book is not about figuring out how to plod through life, getting rid of those pesky habits like smoking and getting better at good habits like eating your vegetables.Itâ€™s about figuring out what you want to do within your time constraints â€” what you want to do with your life â€” and setting up systems that improve your chances of becoming the person you want to be.So buy it, read it, study it, and make these simple techniques part of your life. title: 1 percent better each day

text: Honestly, I'm grown sick of the number of self-help books that I've downloaded, only to find that the key message can be written in a couple of lines, and the rest of the book is taken up with padding out the point.Atomic Habits doesn't do that. It doesn't make grandiose visionary statements, or adopt the "just do it" warrior philosophy. Instead it draws on evidence and practices designed to improve human performance. And instead of focusing on how to be better by pretending to be someone else, it shows you how to be better by paying attention to the small daily practices that will make you better, by consistently doing them.The greatest thing about Atomic Habits is that it accepts humans are weak. Motivation and will are transitory, says Clear. And so, he sets out an approach which allows us to work with who we are, rather than who we wish we were.This book is a series of simple messages, supporting a simple thesis: to make it easy for you to consistently repeat behaviours what will make you a better person.

text: A marketing masterpiece.With all due respect to author's team exceptional ability to better market & monetize original authors' ideas, my two cents is that this is, at its best, a two-page worth of original content which is bulked into an unnecessarily verbose & repetitive three-hundred-something pages book that was mostly a waste of time.The literature not only targets the average Joe out there, but also repeats itself constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. Constantly. And I mean, cons-tant-ly! (I wish this review becomes as successful!)So, to give you the tldr you'd need and save you the trouble:The author reads the Duhig's "power of habit" and Eyal's "hooked" books and starts summerizing "his framework" upon those original ideas. As he mentions himself:"Charles Duhigg and Nir Eyal deserve special recognition for their influence on this image. This representation of the habit loop is a combination of language that was popularized by Duhiggâ€™s book, The Power of Habit, and a design that was popularized by Eyalâ€™s book, Hooked."Here's the original content and the framework he proposes:For good habits:- Make it obvious (cue)- Make it attractive (craving)- Make it easy (response)- Make it satisfying (reward)Do the opposite for the bad ones. And he calls it "The Four Laws of Behavior Change". And the rest is considerable loads of examples and repeatitions. Yup. Millions of sales. Magic.Yup, it's totally fine to expand & build upon others' ideas. It's how human knowledge grows. But come on, it's just 4 sentences. Ok, add one paragraph explanation per each, one example per each and then one page conclusion and that'd be a nice blog post I'd enjoy.â€”P.S. Duhig has also introduced a framework himself:

title: Verbose Unoriginal Refurbished Content

text: Like many other people , i'm a hardcore procrastinator that would get pumped up and motivated to change my life but eventually get burned out after a couple of weeks of non-stop work when that motivational 'high' wears off . I've lost weight multiple times in the past but only to regain it all back. While some of the concepts in the book aren't new , i've read similar books such as 'Mini Habits' by Stephen Guise , 'The Slight Edge' by Jeff Olson and Kaizen Way by Dr Robert Maurer. Atomic Habits are all those books put together on steroids.James Clear explains how setting goals are not the answer but you should focus on  'systems' instead. The system is simply to repeat good habits everyday by making them easy to do, attractive and rewarding.  Yes it will take some time to see big results but the upside is that they stick for good.I learned how to code ,play the guitar and lost more than 100 pounds thanks to Atomic Habits. This is the best self-help book out there and will change your life!

text: I picked this book up because one of the podcasters I listen to, Corinne Crabtree, raved about it and everyone in our Facebook group who picked it up was talking about how great it was. I meant to just take a quick look at the first few pages because I was still in the middle of two other books but Clear's style of writing was so engaging I couldn't put it down.As I was reading I marked down many lines that really resonated with me including ones like "Goals are about the results you want to achieve. Systems are about the processes that lead to those results.". He goes on to talk about how it's usually the system you need to tweak to create habits in order to reach your goals. Subconsciously I realized this but I never really actively thought about it and how I can actively try and tweak my mini-habits to accomplish the things I wanted.I love that at the end of each chapter there is a wrap up of the key points covered in that chapter. He also shows how each of his points layer on top of each other and work together. Great read that I highly recommend!

text: The most impactful book I've ever read about habits was The Power of Habit....and then Atomic Habits came along. James takes everything I loved about The Power of Habit and expands on it here. He mixes the perfect blend of science and stories to get the point across and make you feel like creating new habits is not some daunting task only for special people but for anyone. I found myself nodding along as I listened and stopped it at least a dozen times to take notes.I got at least 4-5 'a-ha' moments about building habits that shattered the conventional wisdom I'd always thought about before. From realizing that I've been approaching will-power the wrong way and the question that I should ask myself next time I want to lose weight or work out.I've been thinking about Atomic Habits since I finished it and cannot wait to dig into it again. I've been recommending it to everyone.

text: I've always been a goal-oriented person and, for the most part, I achieve my goals. But it wasn't until I read James Clear's book, Atomic Habits, that I realized why â€” I have intuitively built habits to support achieving my goals. And I was more focused on the activities I needed to do on a regular basis than the end goal itself. So that even if I didn't achieve my ultimate goal by a timeframe I had set for myself, I always made progress.But I had not done this consciously. Now, after reading this book, I have a full toolset of principles and tips to help me create the life I want to live and be the person I want to be.Clear's methods and principles are not new. He simply sets them out in a way that makes them clear (no pun intended), digestible, and doable. They are commonsense, and they work.This book is a must read if you want to take control of your life.

text: I've read many self improvement books, and with all honesty none have gotten to the point and showed you what to do as well as James Clear has done in this book. Moreover the thing I love the most about implementing the strategies he gives, is that they're really simple and easy to start.When trying to start something new we usually bite too much than we can chew. For example if you want to become fit and aim to go to the gym, you're first few sessions may be really intense but then soon after you'll leave the whole habit. We're trying to improve a habit that we haven't even built. And so instead it is better to start with something as dead simple as just staying at the gym for five minutes, and then steadily increasing it. Long term rather than short term.Moreover, once you finish this book there are several several wonderful articles on his website; Jamesclear.comAll in all, you can't go wrong with this my friend.

text: For those who are at times weak-willed creatures of habit vs. logic (like me), this book is life-changing.  As a general rule you know something is spot-on when it had never occurred to you before, but after reading it, it just seems so obvious.  This book is focused mainly on 1) on setting up systems such as your environmental factors of how you make good or bad habits easier or harder for yourself [e.g. having potato chips in plain view on the counter, or putting your workout clothes out the night before] and 2) how to identify habits, set up goals and hold yourself to them.  I haven't achieved every single habit goal yet, but 6 months after finishing the book I've lost 30 pounds and re-instilled a handful of key good habits that I'd been wanting to get back to for years.

text: â€œMaking a choice that is 1 percent better or 1 percent worse seems insignificant in the moment, but over the span of moments that make up a lifetime these choices determine the difference between who you are and who you could be. Success is the product of daily habitsâ€”not once-in-a-lifetime transformations. That said, it doesnâ€™t matter how successful or unsuccessful you are right now. What matters is whether your habits are putting you on the path toward success. You should be far more concerned with your current trajectory than with your current results.â€œThis book is about strategically building your ideal life and your ideal self. Itâ€™s so easy to imagine how we wish our lives and ourselves were different, but when it comes to taking action, it can be almost paralyzing. We donâ€™t know where to start, we have unconscious beliefs that sabotage ourselves at every turn, environments that no longer serve us, and action plans that lead to burn out, frustration, and backsliding. Jamesâ€™ book offers solutions to all of these problems. With a little clarity, patience and openmindedness, this bookâ€™s wisdom put to use will get you moving towards where youâ€™d like to be.

text: I did warn you I was going to be cheesy: Yep, this book has changed my life.In fact, following James Clear's emails for the past few years has had a hand in changing my life for the better, too.Here's an example: I used to struggle to get up early. I was really, really, REALLY awful at it... yet I do my best work when I get up early. (To me, early is 6.30 am.) I made one simple change based on this book, and now I get up at 6.30 every day. I know, I know, it's a tiny thing â€“ but it's a big deal to me.And that's not the only way my life has changed for the better.This book is on my "must read every year" list, not just because it's full of actionable, practical, non-judgemental advice and info, but because it's an enjoyable read. I teach business owners how to write books, and this is one of the best I've read. There's no filler. No boring preaching. Just great stories and clear actions to take.If you're struggling to build and maintain good habits, and change bad habits, this is the book for you.

After reading this book, instead of focusing on goals I've listed out processes and micro habits it will take to "become" the person I want to identify with. text: This is an excellent read. I've long been an advocate of building new muscles through both small steps and creating conducive environments both personally as well as in my coaching with clients and organisations. James' personal story - about the importance of starting small (aka sweating the small stuff) - and his tenet of consistency over intensity absolutely works. The little and often over time is the thing that transforms lives and this book provides both the framework and pragmatic examples and tips to help you get there. Atomic Habits is going back onto the bookshelf alongside my other favourite 'habits' book, Jeff Olson's The Slight Edge, for reference, revisiting and refreshing. 5 stars

date: Reviewed in the United States ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ on 28 January 2020
title: Thank You James Clear

text: I've been reading James Clear's work for a long time.  In fact, I can remember his first two blogs, one for photography and the other was Passive Panda.  Since that time his exploration of habits and how to modify them has easily equaled or surpassed the work of Charles Duhigg.I would highly recommend this book to anyone looking to improve and build good habits or stifle and destroy bad ones.  As I have the audio version,  one of the reasons I give the book 4/5 is due to the speed at which he speaks, which is not bad and I admit to being spoilt by the professional narrators of two other audiobooks in, Deep Work and Rejectionproof. The other reason is the reliance on the work of social scientists, psychologists, etc.  I realize that a number of books in the self-improvement space use scientific studies from the above-mentioned fields but the scandals concerning p-hacking and failure to replicate experiments make me wonder how valid the examples in this book and books like it really are.Having said all of that, I would not have stuck with James all these years if he did not provide information that was useful and more importantly, actionable. I look forward to reading whatever he writes next.
