text: The kind of writing that makes it feel like the book he wanted to write couldn't have been written much better, even with a large amount of further effort. Very concise, clear, sequential, useful writing that is easy to understand and apply without being boring or taking too long to read. Feels like a structured essay that was brutally pared down to the most important parts.  Chapters are short explanations/summaries of various concepts and strategies (usually focused on one per chapter along with a story or real life example) that are simplified and then fitted to a lightweight, easy to remember framework, allowing for easy recall and individual contextual extrapolation in your real life. As always, different books are better or worse fits for different people at different points in their lives that have different tastes and usage cases. This book has its own style, and if you think it might be a good fit for what you need, you should consider it. I found it fun to read, interesting and useful.

text: I would go so far as to say that "Atomic Habits" is the most important book in the genre of Personal Development. James Clear does an excellent job of explaining how your "habits" dictate your "outcomes"."Atomic Habits" clearly illustrates WHY you do the things you do.  More importantly, James Clear will show you how to transform your life with small (seemingly insignificant) changes in your daily behavior (your habits).  You will understand how these "small changes" will eventually compound into remarkable results.Buy this book, but don't just read it... STUDY IT... IMMERSE YOURSELF IN IT! You will come away with many "aha" moments.I should mention at this junction that I have no affiliation with James Clear -- other than being a huge fan of his teachings. If you're looking for transformation, "Atomic Habits" will deliver.

text: I can't say enough good things about this book and how it's helped me get more done, and have a healthier life. The logic of his steps just make sense. Keep at it and the next thing you know, you're finally feeling productive and overall there is improvement on many levels. My only worry, and the reason I gave it 3 stars is because of the beginning of the book where the author goes on and on about his accomplishments. It smacked of incredible insecurity and unwarranted over the top bravado. I wish he'd had the confidence to just introduce his beliefs and system and allow the process to speak for itself, otherwise I think some people will just stop before they even get to what matters in the book. I'd say ignore the first 1/4, and read the really good ideas that, if you stick to them, even haphazardly in the beginning, eventually before you know it, it all falls into place. You'll be glad you read this book and followed what this man passionately believes in. Good luck :-).

text: "Not another recycled book on habits..." This was my initial thought, but I was mistaken. This is the first habits book that gives you a practical plan for adding new habits, improving existing habits, and removing bad habits. It is a powerful tool chest that you will be able to start using immediately to make improvements. It is written in a way that stacks on the previous lesson, reinforcing the method. By the time you finish reading the book, you will feel like you can finally build habits more predictably and get rid of the ones that are holding you back.The author is an amazing writer. Simple, "clear" style, without fluff. He curates the existing methodologies and science, and presents them in a logical manner within his framework. The supplemental material that accompanies the book is super helpful and he has a journal on the way to help with implementing the process.You now have the tools, so no more excuses.

text: This book is life changing. I have followed James Clear's newsletters for a number of years and was so excited to hear that he  was writing a book. Atomic Habits does not disappoint. I have actually listened to the audio version and bought and studied the written version. Make it Obvious, Attractive, Easy and Satisfying are etched in my brain when I am struggling with any of my current habits that have gone pear shaped  or I am thinking of making changes in my life. James covers it all. I have been a  health care practitioner for almost three decades and a couple of years ago I had a realisation that understanding habit formation is the secret to health and wellbeing when I was struggling myself. We all know what to to do but how do we do it and how do we do it consistently; Atomic Habits is the answer. This book is a must read if you want to take responsibility for your health, wellbeing and your life. Thank you, James.

text: Iâ€™ve followed James Clearâ€™s blog for some time now, and he has always been a very easy read. I love similar content to what he writes about, so he is essentially a â€œshortcutâ€ to learning since he is a more voracious reader/learner than I.I enjoyed this book and think James did a wonderful job piggy-backing off his well-read background while retaining his own unique voice. This was not someone regurgitating what other people have written, but rather him taking all that he has learned and formulating it into a completed puzzle for our consumption.One thing that is tricky with books like this is that they are so easy to read that sometimes you forget they are only useful if you stop, think, and implement the suggestions into your day-to-day. text: I have been a subscriber of James's email for a number of years and have always thoroughly enjoyed his writing. It's practical, useful and always well presented. As soon as he announced his book, I was straight on Amazon to pre-order. Although it only arrived today, I had the chance to listen to an early audio book copy. It's absolutely superb!This book is as practical as the content of his email newsletters, and I intend on reading (or listening to) this book multiple times over so I can 'extract' as much value from it as possible. He offers background, context, stories and more, to illustrate each of his points. As with all books of this nature, merely listening is not enough; application and implementation is key to gaining value from it.There's a good amount of additional supporting material that you can download too (links are in the book). So you not only get the book to read, but lots of extras to help you make use of what is taught.It's an engaging listen (or read) and comes highly recommended by me! If you're unsure, search online for "James Clear", have a read of some of his content, and make a decision.

title: Pedalling the easy answers

text: Everyone has habits that need changing - things you need to stop doing (smoking, procrastinating) and things you need to start doing more of (exercising, writing). This is a useful guide to the tricks you can use to help you develop good habits and rid yourself of bad ones. For example: Habit needs to become part of your identity (not "I have to go the the gym", but "I am a healthy person"). Make good habits easy to do and bad ones inconvenient (put fruit on your kitchen counter, but hide the cookies). Four points are key: Cue-craving-response-reward.All useful stuff - and worth reminding yourself of now and again. But there is nothing terribly new in this book. I preferred Charles Duhigg's earlier "The Power of Habit". This book is worth a quick read, and some of the examples are fun. Certainly, if you follow some of the hints, you will acquire better habits. But not worth five stars.

text: This is a really useful book. I've read a lot about habits because it's a fascinating subject and because I would like to control mine. Atomic Habits is perfect for the latter purpose.The writing is very straightforward. James Clear deconstructs the habit loop and offers ideas and strategies for making changes at each level in order to help building or getting rid of habits. He talks about the research on which he bases his ideas, and illustrates them with stories, but only as much as it is necessary. The content is focused on applicable ideas and the structure is very easy to follow. He also summarizes each chapter at the end, which is very useful, and offers additional online resources.If you want to create for yourself a strategy for building a good set of habits, this book is great to have around.

title: work on your habits putting the atoms together bit by bit

text: This isn't the first time I've read a book Frankensteined together from a blogger's blog. And that the original blog posts were Frankensteined together with info gleaned from books by other people. Like BJ Fogg, founder of the Behaviour Design Lab at Stanford (the Tiny Habits guy). Don't get me wrong, it's good to have all these behaviour tips from lots of different experts in one place. Let's face facts, it saves you having to read all the books James Clear has read on the subject. And I'll undoubtedly re-read it and extract notes next time. But from my initial read, I just felt there was something not quite right about it. It didn't quite flow. Like it wasn't put together in the right order, know what I mean? title: Another blogger compiled a book

text: Â I was so excited to finally read this book! When it arrived, I noticed the book along with its pages were bent up.After looking closely at the front of the book, I noticed the alignment of the font for: â€œThe International Bestsellerâ€ was off. Itâ€™s not centred at all. In addition, the pages were printer paper thin and you can see right through to the other pages as well. If you like highlighting your books while reading, this is no good because the highlighter will bleed onto the other pages.Also, the font is extremely tiny and you can just tell that this is a carbon copy of the real book thatâ€™s being sold in store or on other bookstores online. Iâ€™ve also seen this book in person at a bookstore! So I just knew this purchase was off.I buy the majority of my books on Amazon because itâ€™s cheaper and I love itâ€™s efficient service. However, I am very disappointed in this purchase and Lux Canada should be flagged.Thereâ€™s no need to replicate books and then profit from it. Thatâ€™s not honest or fair.With good judgment and a few scans through the book, you can easily tell by the quality and make of this book is that it was photocopied.Please be aware and do your due diligence when buying books outside of your local bookstore, but most importantly from Lux Canada.Amazon, please look into this!

text: This book came to me as amazon recommended. I thought, oh great, another book on building good habits. But I took a glance at it, and decided to look deeper, so I bought a copy. It completely changed my thinking about setting and focusing on goals. I had fallen into the same trap the author writes about. I would set an ambitious goal, with no particular system for achieving that goal. I wasn't consistent about my goals. Sometimes I did the small 1% steps to get to the goal, other times I would do something a few times and give up. It was purely by chance whether I would stick to something or not. What I've learned from the book is to be systematic about my approach. Even more important to to align my identity to the goal I want to achieve.

text: I have been receiving James Clear's newsletter for several months so when the book got out I ordered the kindle version immediately. If you have never read anything about habit forming, you will benefit from this book. But if you have, I don't see what you can get from Atomic Habits. I am also becoming tired of all the personal success stories from book authors because they can't be applied to the layman. I found there was nothing to learn from James' baseball days, as I never was an athlete and never excelled in sport. Feels like the average reader can't do this. text: I can't find fault with this book. It's quite simply the best and most informative book on habits and how to change them.There's so much insight into human psychology and how it manifests in our daily habits. However, James Clear goes further by showing how the challenges of modern life complicates our efforts to make meaningful changes and how to overcome them. We are bombarded with cues from our environment that the primitive brain is naturally drawn towards and this explains a lot of our habit formation.Atomic Habits is packed with strategies to start changing habits today. Given it is 2 January 2020, I'm excited to trade in meaningless resolutions for actual behavioural change strategies that work.

text: I bought this book because I am a big believer in building habits and predictable routines in one's personal and work life. I read the whole book. I was disappointed.Pros:- Links identity and habits. You are what you do. From that point of view, just going to the gym makes you the type of person who works out, even if you don't do much of a workout.- Introduces the idea that habits bring cumulative benefits like compound interest. While not obviously always the case, it's a powerful idea that definitely applies in areas like meditation or physical training, where the observable changes are minimal at first.Cons:- The book doesn't delve into examples of good habits and the why and how to build them. It stays at the meta / generic level, leaving the reader to think about what habits they may want to build.- The overall principles for building good habits are sound, even if high level and a bit obvious (make the good habits easy, the bad ones hard, etc).- The book is way too long for what it has to convey. Often things repeat or you wonder when the next chapter or thought will start, and when that happens, you lose track of what the earlier one was about -- mainly due to their length.Overall, not recommended.

title: Fantastic book

text: This book is a must-read for anyone who wants to build good habits and break bad ones (And who doesn't ?).Unlike most books I'd read on the subject, "Atomic Habits" is neither an autobiography nor a purely theoretical piece of writing. In fact, it is a real hands-on book and the strategies it contains can be applied immediately.The major concept of the book is to focus on small but consistent improvement. The author argues that "just as atoms are the building blocks of molecules, atomic habits are the building blocks of remarkable results". According to James Clear, there are four stages that are crucial when it comes to creating good habits (and breaking bad ones):1. Cue -Make it obvious (invisible)2. Craving - Make it attractive (unattractive)3. Response - Make it easy (difficult)4. Reward - Make it satisfying (unsatisfying)In my opinion "Atomic Habits" is a treasure for anyone seriously interested in personal development and self-improvement.

title: Disappointing

text: First of all: don't buy this version of the book. Incredible poor quality, torn pages, poor formatting, suddenly different fonts appear, etc.Content-wise: I kept reading many recommendations about this book and eventually bought it. Therefore, I probably held high expecations of it which were increased when James Clear claims that he would extend findings of luminaries such as B.F. Skinner. Long story short: he does not.From start to end the book remains very superficial. I am sure there are many good take aways for readers who have no prior (or scientific) knowledge about this topic. Others I recommend to watch a Youtube-Video of the author. That's all you need - the rest of the book are just stories.A better book for this type of content is "Switch" by the Heath brothers.Readers of this book should also be very cautious from a psychological perspective. Creating habits can be very helpful but if you overdue it (like it is frequently suggested in this book) you might be prone to a life characterized by compulsiveness and unease.
